content.articleContent:
Understanding Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)

Your aorta is your body’s main blood vessel that runs from your heart through the center of your chest and stomach (abdomen). It’s your body’s main supplier of blood, and a rupture to it can cause life-threatening bleeding.

This rupture commonly happens when the aorta’s thick wall is weakened or damaged. It forms a bulge or a balloon, called an aneurysm. Though an aneurysm can occur in any blood vessel, they occur most often in the abdominal (stomach) portion of the aorta. This is called an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.

What are the symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm?

Though three out of four people show no symptoms, some people feel stomach or low back pain.

Who’s at risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm?

  • Men over the age of 60 have the highest occurrence.
  • Family history increases your risk.
  • Chances increase if you have high blood pressure.
  • Risk gets higher if you smoke.
  • Chances increase with age.

What are my options if I have an abdominal aortic aneurysm?

Your vascular surgeon will recommend specific tests and treatment based on the size of the aneurysm and how fast it’s growing. Treatment may include monitoring, surgical repair, or endovascular stent graft repair.

Allergy Testing and Treatment

Allergies are more than just a nuisance; in extreme cases, they can actually be life-threatening. Whether it's a specific food or an environmental factor, identifying the source of your allergies is an important step toward managing your symptoms and feeling your best. After thorough allergy testing, our experts can help you understand what's triggering your symptoms and develop a treatment plan designed to help prevent allergic reactions and reduce your discomfort.

View our Allergy and Immunology Specialists.

Other Conditions We Treat

Our allergy and immunology expertise encompasses a number of other conditions. Together, we can identify common sensitivities and help you get your symptoms under control.

Asthma

Whether you're living with ongoing asthma or your symptoms develop only when you get sick or encounter certain allergens, seeking treatment is recommended. We will create a treatment plan to provide short term relief and long-term control of your asthma symptoms.

Children's Asthma

Asthma is a common and growing condition among school-aged children. For a child suffering from asthma, every day brings new challenges and the fear that breathing could become difficult at any time.

Our goal is to help families overcome the limitations and debilitating symptoms associated with childhood asthma. With comprehensive treatment we provide, the frequency and severity of asthma symptoms may be reduced, allowing your child to a more active life.

Sinus Issues

Are you plagued by chronic sinus infections, sinus headaches, blockages or other unbearable sinus issues? Sinus conditions can be caused by many things, from allergies to anatomical factors. And the symptoms of sinus problems can include snoring, congestion, debilitating headaches and obstructed breathing, among others. Our providers can diagnose and treat sinus issues.

Skin Conditions

Contact Dermatitis

Contact dermatitis is a type of rash that causes your skin to get red, itch, and in some cases, feel like it’s burning. There are two main classifications for contact dermatitis - allergic and irritant. While the triggers for each are different, the reactions and treatment recommendations are very similar.

Most of the time, contact dermatitis can be treated at home, but in some cases you may need to see a specialist. After a few days, if the rash has not responded to treatment and is painful, you should contact our office to be seen.

Hives

Hives can be caused by a number of factors, from bug bites to food reactions to environmental triggers. And unfortunately, hives can be itchy and irritating, causing undue amounts of discomfort. We will analyze your condition and recommend solutions to alleviate the symptoms associated with hives outbreaks.

Ezcema

Eczema (also called atopic dermatitis) affects between 15 and 20 percent of school-age children and as many as 10 percent of adults. This chronic condition causes itchy, inflamed skin that is sometimes accompanied by asthma or allergy symptoms. Although some over-the-counter treatments can be helpful in treating and preventing eczema flare-ups, professional dermatologic care often offers the best results. Our skincare team can help you gain control of your eczema and experience increased confidence and improved quality of life.

Patient-centered Care That Enhances Quality of Life

Learning that a loved one has Alzheimer’s disease or dementia can turn your world upside-down. There are countless questions around care options and finding the right care for your loved one’s changing needs.

We understand the uncertainty that can come with this kind of diagnosis, which is why our neurologists work closely with families and caregivers to develop a treatment and care plan.

You’re not alone in this journey. Whether you have questions about providing in-home care or joining a support group, our specialists will be here for you every step of the way.

About Angiography

Angiography is an x-ray study of the arteries. This procedure involves injecting a contrast material (x-ray dye) into a blood vessel to make it visible on an x-ray. The dye is placed directly in the artery through a very small flexible tube called a catheter, which is inserted in to the artery through a small nick in the skin.

The procedure is often used to detect abnormalities of the blood vessels, such as narrowing and blockage caused by fatty deposits or blood clots, and aneurysms (defined as weakening or ballooning of the wall of the artery). Angiography can also detect abnormal patterns of blood vessels caused by tumors and can show sites of internal bleeding. Demonstrating these blood vessel abnormalities can help the physician determine the extent of the disease and determine the best treatment option.

Manage Your Anticoagulant Medications

ProMedica’s Jobst Medication Therapy Management (Jobst MTM) through Jobst Vascular Institute offers many clinical services including an anticoagulation service. Our anticoagulation service helps people who take an anticoagulant (blood thinner to prevent blood clots) safely and effectively manage their medication. It has been shown that patients who are monitored by an anticoagulation service receive the most effective treatment to reduce their risk of new blood clots or bleeding.

Warfarin is dosed based on your international normalized ratio (INR) which is the number of seconds it takes for your blood to clot.

Other anticoagulants such as Lovenox, Eliquis, and Xarelto can be measured by Anti-Xa levels to determine the amount of drug in the body that blocks the clotting factor Xa.

All of these medications are monitored based on your kidney function, liver function, and other lab results. Overall lifestyle and other medications you take can also affect your anticoagulant medication so we will work closely with you to make sure that you are taking the safest and most effective dose for you.

Why do people take an anticoagulant?

An anticoagulant is prescribed to prevent harmful blood clots from forming or to treat an existing blood clot. Physicians commonly recommend taking an anticoagulant medication for conditions including:

  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Blood clotting disorders
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Following a heart attack
  • Presence of a heart valve
  • Leg bypass
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Valvular heart disease

What help will I get managing my blood thinners?

Our anticoagulation service will:

  • Provide careful outpatient monitoring of labs and adjust your anticoagulant medication as needed to make sure you are taking the most safe and effective dose
  • Answer your questions about your anticoagulant medication and provide ongoing education for you and your family
  • Review all of your medications and help as medications are added, adjusted, or stopped to make sure adjustments are made with any identified interactions
  • Explain how diet, over-the-counter medications, and supplements can affect your anticoagulant medication
  • Help when you need to stop and restart an anticoagulant medication for a procedure or surgery
  • Refill your anticoagulant medication prescription and help with affordability options
  • Help resolve any side effects you may be experiencing

What other services does Jobst Medication Therapy Management (Jobst MTM) offer?

  • Diabetes medication management
  • Full medication review

How do I get started with anticoagulation services?

If you are interested in having our anticoagulation service manage your anticoagulant medication, please have your doctor send our service a referral or call us at 419-291-2010 for more information.

Helping Your Child Grow and Thrive

Most children face some form of anxiety as they grow up. Changes in school, social life and physical development can all play a part in typical childhood stress. But if anxiety keeps your child from leading a full and happy life, it may be time to find help.

ProMedica’s pediatric behavioral health specialists know how to work with children at every age and stage. As a parent or guardian, you can count on our expertise and lean on our support. We’ll walk every step of this journey together. Our work isn’t finished until your child is facing a brighter tomorrow.

content.articleContent:
We're Here to Protect Your Heart

As your largest vessel, your aorta performs the vital job of delivering oxygenated blood from your heart to the rest of your body. But over time, it can balloon, separate or tear. These problems put you at risk for an aortic rupture that needs medical attention right away.

At ProMedica, our cardiothoracic team stands ready to care for you — day-to-day and in emergencies. They can diagnose and monitor your aortic heart disease and can recommend when you may need aortic surgery.

Aquatic Therapy Rehab

If you are recovering from an injury, surgery or illness and experiencing pain or weakness that makes it difficult to exercise then aquatic therapy may be right for you. Various conditions that may benefit from aquatic therapy include:

  • Total joint replacements
  • Low back pain
  • Pediatric neurological conditions
  • Multiple injuries following a car accident
  • Fracture healing
  • Generalized weakness following prolonged illness

Which ProMedica locations offer aquatic therapy?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide aquatic therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.

  • Please consult with your physician to determine if aquatic therapy is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

What Is Arrhythmia?

Arrhythmia is an irregular heart rate or rhythm that causes poor blood flow to your body. Some arrhythmias increase your risk for having a stroke. If you or for a loved one is diagnosed with arrhythmia, it’s natural to have questions. A ProMedica electrophysiologist in the Toledo area can help you determine whether you or a loved one are experiencing arrhythmia.

Understanding Arrhythmia

What are the most common kinds of arrhythmia?

  • Atrial fibrillation (AFib): Fast, irregular heartbeat.
  • Tachycardia: Fast, but regular heartbeat.
  • Bradycardia: A slow heartbeat.

How does arrhythmia work?

The heart is an electrical pump. Normally, electrical impulses start every beat of your heart and keep your heart beating with a nice, regular rhythm.

But sometimes those rhythms become chaotic, irregular or rapid. The upper parts of your heart get out of sync with the lower parts of your heart.

How does arrhythmia feel?

Some people have no symptoms at all, while some have different sensations. You may notice these feelings occasionally, often, or all of the time. You may describe the feeling in your chest like this:

  • A fish flopping
  • A drum pounding
  • Butterflies fluttering
  • Your heart leaping out of your chest
  • Your heart skipping a beat, and then your heart racing

You may also feel:

  • Lightheaded
  • Nervous
  • Out of breath
  • Weak
  • Dizzy
  • Tired

What causes arrhythmia?

Electrical flaws or damage to the heart are the most common causes. However some people with arrhythmia have none of these.

Why should you be concerned?
Arrhythmia, especially AFib, increases your risk for stroke by five times that of a person without arrhythmia. Your atypical heartbeat allows blood to pool in your heart, where a blood clot can form. Eventually the clot may dislodge and travel to your brain. This causes a stroke.

ProMedica’s cardiac electrophysiologists have the expertise to help you determine the best diagnosis and treatment for your arrhythmia.

What is a cardiac electrophysiologist?

This specially trained cardiologist treats patients who have rhythm problems with their hearts.

Learn more about cardiac electrophysiology

Help Your Child Regain Control

When your child has a hard time breathing, it can be hard to catch your breath, too. That’s why our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses and respiratory therapists are here to help.

content.articleContent:
Expert treatment that helps you live a full and healthy life

If you’ve been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, you’re not alone. AFib is the most common heart rhythm problem in the United States, and it affects at least three million Americans today.

At ProMedica, you’ll benefit from cutting-edge technology and cardiac expertise. Our goal is to make sure you get the treatment you need to live a full and healthy life.

A Center Dedicated to Irregular Heartbeats

ProMedica’s Heart Rhythm Center is a new, state-of-the-art facility on the second floor of ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Providing the highest quality of heart rhythm care in Toledo, the center treats simple to complex heart arrhythmias, such as AFib.

Learn more about the Heart Rhythm Center

Understanding ADHD

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is one of the most common childhood developmental disorders.

Typically symptoms start developing before age 7. Children with ADHD may appear overly hyper, compulsive, active or unable to focus. These symptoms create significant challenges in at least two areas of their day-to-day life – home, social settings, school, activities or work (for adults).

Remember that everyone matures differently. Behaviors shouldn’t cause concern unless they are more severe or frequent than in other children the same age. Additional factors – personality, temperament, energy or other health conditions – are sometimes mistaken for ADHD. Because of this, careful diagnosis is crucial. The evaluation process typically includes several tests performed by a behavioral health professional.

What are the common ADHD symptoms? Signs are grouped into three areas:

Inattention

  • Easily distracted
  • Does not appear to listen
  • Avoids or dislikes tasks requiring sustained mental effort
  • Struggles to follow through on instructions – especially multiple steps
  • Frequently forgets or misplaces belongings

Hyperactivity

  • Has difficulty doing quiet activities
  • Excessively fidgets or talks; squirmy
  • Has difficulty remaining seated
  • Acts as if driven by a motor

Impulsivity

  • Blurts out answers before questions have been completed
  • Frequently makes unnecessary mistakes or take risks
  • Interrupts others
  • Has difficulty waiting or taking turns

What should you do if your think your child has ADHD? Contact your pediatrician to discuss. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional.

content.articleContent:
Compassionate, Specialized Care for Your Child’s Needs

Facing an autism diagnosis can send a family into a whirlwind of uncertainty. It’s normal to feel overwhelmed with questions and concerns about your child’s future.

At ProMedica, our goal is to ease your fears, answer your questions and provide critical support services for the whole family.

Wherever you are in your child’s autism journey, know that our doctors and specialists are available to provide the resources your child needs to live a happy and healthy life.

Understanding Balance Disorders

Balance related falls account for more than half of all accidental deaths among the elderly; however, balance disorders can occur at any age.

  • Do you continuously feel dizzy when trying to perform day to day activities such as walking?
  • Do you often fall or feel as though you are going to fall?

Our experts at ProMedica Total Rehab can help you manage your balance disorder through our educational resources and treatment.

What is a balance disorder?

A balance disorder is a condition that makes you feel unsteady or dizzy. Often, if you are lying down, sitting or being still, it may feel as though you or the area around you is moving. If you are walking, it may feel as though you will tip over.

How is a balance disorder diagnosed and treated?

A qualified, licensed physical therapist can perform a thorough evaluation of your balance disorder by observing your posture and movement. By comparing the results of your evaluation testing with established norms, your therapist will determine the strengths and weaknesses of your individual balance system. Your therapist will work with you to develop a treatment plan and exercises for you to perform at home.

How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, we are committed to helping you regain control over your balance disorder.

  • Talk to your physician to determine if this treatment is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

About Balloon Sinuplasty

Balloon sinuplasty is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and sinus-related pain. Unlike traditional sinus surgery, it does not require cutting or removing any bone or tissue from the nose. Instead, it uses a small, flexible balloon catheter, which is inserted through the nose to open up blocked sinuses and decrease pressure.

 

Balloon sinuplasty is performed at our Adrian location.

Look and Feel Your Best

Achieving your weight loss goals isn’t just about looking good — it’s about lifelong health.

Perhaps you’ve tried dieting and exercise, but still aren’t seeing the results you want. Or you may be concerned about high blood pressure, diabetes or another weight-related condition. Whatever your reasons are, it may be time to think about having weight loss surgery.

ProMedica is here to help you decide if a bariatric procedure is right for you. Our expert team can guide you through every step of the process. We’ll explain all your treatment choices and make sure you understand what to expect before, during and after surgery. We’re your partners on the journey to a lasting weight loss solution.

content.articleContent:
Find Hope for a Brighter Tomorrow

Most of us don’t think twice about getting help for our physical concerns. But we often hesitate when it comes to our mental well-being. Yet nearly half of us will have a mental or emotional issue at some point in our lives, so it’s important to know that help is near.

Early intervention to help prevent health problems is just as vital for the mind and emotions as it is for the body. Get the right diagnosis and find the best possible treatment, so you can feel like yourself again.

Download Mental Health Resource Guides

  • Northwest Ohio Mental Health Resource Guide
  • Lenawee Resource Guide
  • Download the Monroe Resource Guide

Download Hospital Resource Guides

ProMedica Flower Hospital Patient Rights and the Grievance Procedure booklet

Help Us Advance Medical Research, Locally

You're having a surgery or medical procedure. You want to take it a step further and make a difference in the lives of others affected by cancer and disease. What about contributing to medical research advancement at the ProMedica BioRepository?

It’s so simple to donate your blood and body tissue samples.

Biorepository FAQs

What is the ProMedica BioRepository?

It’s a “bank” that stores tissue or blood samples, called biospecimens, that can be used to help researchers discover new treatments for cancer and other medical conditions. The ProMedica BioRepository is located on the ProMedica Toledo Hospital campus and it’s your local answer to helping others and furthering medicine.

What do the researchers do with tissue and blood samples?

An ultra low-temperature laboratory freezer preserves your samples for long term storage. The research on these samples can be used to discover what causes cancer, how to prevent it, and how to treat it. It can also help us learn the causes of and find treatments for other diseases such as:

  • Diabetes
  • Alzheimer's Disease
  • Heart disease
  • Crohn's Disease

Where do tissue and blood samples come from?

You have the ability to easily donate your tissues and blood samples if you’re undergoing a procedure. At your scheduled pre-op appointment, you may request the blood samples taken during your procedure be donated to our ProMedica BioRepository. As for tissue donation, your doctor removes a certain amount of tissue needed for your diagnosis or treatment during your procedure. But sometimes, there’s extra tissue. In most situations, this tissue is destroyed. Instead of destroying what’s left over, you may choose to have it donated to the ProMedica BioRepository.

Will donating affect diagnostic results?

No, your leftover tissue donation will not affect your diagnostic results.

How much blood do you need to donate?

For blood samples, you’ll be asked for permission for an additional four to six teaspoons to store in the BioRepository. It’s done at the same time as your scheduled blood workup, so no separate appointment is needed.

Can you be identified from your donation?

No. Identification of all donated samples is replaced with a code, which allows for de-identified tissue donation.

Is it safe?

Yes. You don’t need to go through any extra procedures or tests. The remaining tissue leftover from your procedure is all that’s needed.

How do you do it?

If you’re interested, please speak with your doctor. When you come in for pre-admission testing or for a procedure, a ProMedica BioRepository member may speak with you and give you the choice to participate. For further information, please call 419-291-4584.

Learn more about the Biorepository.

title: Bipolar Disorder Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System

content.articleContent:
Understanding Bipolar Disorder

Bipolar disorder is a mental disorder that causes identifiable and sometimes intense changes in mood and energy level. Someone with bipolar disorder may experience periods of high energy (manic periods) followed by periods of depression or lethargy (depressive periods). The exact cause is unknown, but research suggests that it is hereditary, as it often runs in families. Studies are still underway to try and identify which gene (or genes) may be responsible.

Signs of Bipolar Disorder

Someone with bipolar disorder will experience both types of the following symptoms to a varying degree:

Manic symptoms:

  • Has an overly inflated sense of self-esteem
  • Seems to not need sleep or rest as much
  • Is very distracted and irritable
  • Excessively gets involved in high-risk and/or pleasurable activities, for example: sexual promiscuity, reckless driving, reckless spending, substance abuse
  • Enhanced talkativeness
  • Appears to have excessive “high” or euphoric feelings, grandiose at times
  • Unpredictably changes mood from happy or silly, anger or agitation
  • Increased sex drive
  • Increased energy level
  • Uses uncharacteristic poor judgment

Depressive symptoms:

  • Difficulty with relationships
  • Expresses excessive guilt
  • Expresses hopelessness
  • Is extremely sensitive to failure or rejection
  • Is unable to concentrate
  • Lacks energy
  • Lacks interest in activities once enjoyed
  • Persistently suffers sadness
  • Seems irritable, hostile or aggressive
  • Shares feelings of wanting to die
  • Shows changes in appetite or weight
  • Shows signs of low self-esteem
  • Sleeps too much or very little
  • Thinks about suicide or attempts suicide

If you think you may have bipolar disorder, talk to your primary care doctor. After ruling out other conditions through a physical exam, they can help you find a psychiatrist, psychologist or other behavioral health specialist with experience in treating bipolar disorder.

Bipolar Disorder in Children and Adolescents

Bipolar disorder is a condition with alternating sets of symptoms. During certain periods of time, your child or adolescent may act extremely happy, elated, or very irritable (manic symptoms). During the alternate periods of time they will exhibit symptoms of major depression.

When symptoms are present before age 12, they are sometimes confused with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, advances continue to be made in recognizing bipolar disorder in younger children.

If you believe your child has bipolar disorder, contact your pediatrician or family doctor to set up an appointment for evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your doctor may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. Bipolar disorder can be effectively treated, usually with a combination of therapy and medication.

ProMedica's Blood Management Program

Bloodless care is for patients who decline a blood transfusion under any circumstance, whether it be for cultural, religious or personal reasons. Blood management is our broader program for patients who prefer to avoid a blood transfusion, if possible.

For both bloodless care and blood management patients, we utilize the same best practices to prevent anemia and minimize bleeding caused by surgery or illness. Together, you and our physician-lead team will develop a plan based on your individual needs.

The goal of ProMedica’s progressive blood management program is helping you avoid an unneccessary blood transfusion.

Reasons to avoid a blood transfusion when possible include:

  • Decrease risk of infections
  • Reduce exposure to viruses and other blood-borne diseases
  • Shorten the length of your hospital stay
  • Conserve our precious community resource

Why trust ProMedica’s blood management program?

One of the few programs in the country, ProMedica began its blood management program with a bloodless care program in 1993. For the past twenty years we have established ourselves as a leader of blood management and bloodless care in our region, our knowledgeable doctors are able to perform procedures such as open-heart, orthopaedic and gastrointestinal surgeries without the need for blood transfusions.

Our team includes an expert physician medical director and dedicated registered nurses. We offer a wide range of strategies to minimize blood loss and improve red blood cell production. Many treatments can take place at a ProMedica infusion center.

As an active member in the the Society for the Advancement of Blood Management (SABM), we have access to the latest industry resources and techniques available to provide the best recommendations for you. 

Treatment Strategies

Often there are proactive steps that lessen or eliminate your need for a blood transfusion. These may include:

Before Surgery

  • Iron (oral or intravenous)
  • B12, folic acid, vitamin C
  • Medications
  • Nutritional education planning
  • Synthetic erythropoietin

During Surgery

  • Electrocautery
  • Hemodilution
  • Hemostatic drug therapy
  • Intraoperative blood cell recovery and reinfusion

 

  • Meticulous surgical technologies
  • Minimally invasive surgery
  • Thrombin and adhesives
  • Volume expanders

After Surgery

  • Erythropoietin and iron
  • Minimal blood draws

How do you know if you need a blood management evaluation?

Don’t hesitate to talk with your doctor if you:

  • Develop anemia
  • Have a surgery or procedure scheduled that could result in blood loss

What happens during a blood management evaluation?

You’ll have an in-person or phone call consultation with one of our knowledgeable nurses. Most likely, blood tests will be ordered. After your consultation and review of your blood test results, a treatment plan meeting your specific needs will be developed and shared with you and your physician.

In most cases, any pre- and post-surgery treatments can take place in one of ProMedica’s convenient infusion centers. After your care, our blood management team will follow up with you and your physician.

Talk with your physician to discuss if you are a candidate for the blood management program. Call ProMedica’s blood management program at 419-824-1222.

Care that Delivers Lifesaving Results

Most brain aneurysms don’t cause any health problems. But pressure placed on nerves and nearby brain tissue can sometimes cause aneurysms to rupture and bleed within the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).

When the worst happens, you can count on ProMedica for expert and compassionate care. Using the latest technology and therapies, our neurologists, neurosurgeons, interventional vascular neurologists, and neuroradiologists work together with one goal: to safely place you on the path to recovery.

If you think you may be having an aneurysm rupture, call 911 right away.

Empowering You with Hope and Healing

A diagnosis of brain cancer can be challenging to accept. It may be a scary time for you and your loved ones as you face the days ahead.

You aren’t alone. The cancer care experts at ProMedica are here to help provide the strength you and your family need for the challenges ahead. We use the latest technology to diagnose and treat a wide variety of brain cancers.

At ProMedica, you’ll find expertise that gives you the energy and courage for the best possible outcomes.

content.articleContent:
Your Brain Health Is in Expert Hands

If you’ve been diagnosed with a brain tumor, you’ll need to make some major decisions about your care. We understand this can feel overwhelming. But you’re not alone.

At ProMedica, our whole team — which includes highly specialized neurosurgeons, medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, pathologists, radiologists and nurses — joins together to support every step of your care. And we want you to feel secure in the combined expertise of ProMedica Neurosciences Institute and ProMedica Cancer Institute.

You’ll benefit from a complete spectrum of services. They include diagnosis, evaluation, treatment and follow-up care.

Image Guided Breast Biopsy

Early detection is key to breast health. You and your doctor have decided a breast biopsy is the best choice. One such biopsy type is an image guided breast biopsy. Be assured in our prompt, efficient service so you can know; the sooner the better.

What is an image guided breast biopsy?

It’s an office procedure that’s minimally invasive, which means it doesn’t involve surgery, requires very little time to perform, and results in minimal discomfort for you.

It gives your radiologist greater visibility and greater accuracy to reach the part of your breast that may be in question. It requires a local anesthetic, a nick in your skin, and a small, ultrasound-guided tool to navigate the area.

What are the benefits of image guided breast biopsy over conventional biopsies?

The common benefits to you are:

  • Less discomfort
  • Fewer after-effects
  • A smaller incision

Is image guided breast biopsy the best choice for you?

This is a decision for you and your doctor. Openly discuss the options, benefits and effectiveness.

Want to know more? Easily access this test and further information from the Breast Care Center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.

Meet the Challenges of Breast Cancer with Confidence

Breast cancer is the second most common cancer diagnosed in women in the United States. Fortunately, more women than ever are seeking diagnosis and treatment.

Still, it's never easy to be diagnosed with breast cancer. If you or your doctor find something suspicious in your breast, you may feel overwhelmed. And the journey ahead can seem uncertain. With ProMedica Cancer Institute, you’ll find encouragement and assurance every step of the way.

Our teams are recognized as the region’s leading experts in breast cancer care. They also have access to the most current research and technology in the field. We understand this common cancer can feel like it’s upending your life, but you can be confident you’re moving forward to the best possible outcome.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Breast MRI

You want a thorough understanding of your breast health. A breast MRI is an advanced technique that, when paired with conventional mammography, gives you and your doctor even more information to grasp your condition and act with targeted accuracy.

What is breast MRI?

Breast MRI is sophisticated MRI technology that uses a computer, magnetic field, and radio waves – instead of X-rays – to produce images of your breast tissue.

Remember that breast MRI doesn’t replace mammography, but is a powerful tool used to provide additional information about your breast health.

For which conditions is a breast MRI used?

It can be used for various conditions and situations, including:

  • Determine cancer’s extent
  • Evaluate patients with positive surgical margins for residual cancer
  • Monitor cancer therapy
  • Exclude cancer’s existence in high-risk women
  • Detect occult cancer
  • Characterize lesions
  • Evaluate implant integrity and detect cancer in women with breast augmentation

Is breast MRI offered near you?

In early 2019, our Breast MRI department underwent a renovation and installed a Siemens 1.5T Aera MRI machine right here in northwest Ohio at the Breast Care Center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.

Surviving Cancer with Rehabilitation

You’re ready to move past living with your cancer treatment side effects and want to be stronger, more vibrant, and feel better. You’re a survivor. We’re right here with you.

Cancer treatment can be very toxic and often causes significant pain, fatigue and disability for survivors. Through our cancer rehab program, we help survivors minimize these side effects to have the best quality of life possible.

As a patient, you'll receive comprehensive cancer rehabilitation treatment to improve the symptoms affecting your daily functioning and quality of life. You’re ready to work through side effects such as fatigue, weakness, insomnia, memory loss, fear, anxiety, and depression. You’re ready to enjoy life.

Frequently Asked Questions About Cancer Rehab

Is cancer rehabilitation covered by my health insurance?

Yes. Cancer rehabilitation services are reimbursable by health most insurance providers. You get access to world-class follow up cancer care, without added medical costs.

When should I start cancer rehab treatment?

Any time you and your doctor feel you’re ready. Whether you’ve just begun or are finished with your treatment, or if you experience late effects or unresolved issues from long-ago treatment, we’re here. No matter your prognosis, cancer stage, or recovery phase. You just need your doctor’s referral.

What kind of health care professional provides cancer rehabilitation treatment?

Our rehabilitation care is specially trained to treat survivors of all forms of cancer. They’re medical experts at the top of their fields and comprise a variety of disciplines:

  • Doctors
  • Physical therapists
  • Occupational therapists
  • Speech and swallowing therapists
  • Registered dietitians and nutritionists
  • Mental health professionals

How will you know what services I need?

After a thorough doctor’s evaluation, you’re assigned to a team of medical specialists according to your individual needs. You’ll get a personalized rehabilitation plan, with goals like increased strength and energy, pain alleviation, improved physical function, emotional balance, and an immune system boost.

We take into consideration these factors that impact physical healing:

  • Diet
  • Sleep issues
  • Existing pain, endurance
  • Strength
  • Exercise habits
  • Emotional outlook

What should I bring to my first visit?

Please wear comfortable clothing and walking shoes suitable to physical activity. To your first visit, bring your

  • Insurance card.
  • Medical history information.
  • Current medications and dosage list.
  • Physician referral if your doctor office did not send it directly to your rehab site.

content.articleContent:
About Carotid Artery Disease

Carotid artery disease, also called carotid artery stenosis, is a common cause for stroke. You want to understand more about this vascular disease and the risks for yourself, or for someone you care for.

The carotid arteries are the main blood vessels, one on each side of your neck, that carry blood up to your brain. If you’re diagnosed with this disease, it means a fatty deposit (plaque) has built up in one or both of the carotid arteries and this plaque is restricting blood flow to your brain. Pieces of this plaque can break off and briefly block the artery, causing a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or “mini stroke,” or break off and completely block the artery, causing a stroke.

Understanding Chemotherapy

Your doctor has recommended chemotherapy and you want to know what this means for you. What is chemotherapy? It’s the use of medications to treat cancer. Depending on the cancer type and its stage, chemotherapy is used to treat cancer, keep it from spreading, slow its cell growth, or to relieve its symptoms.

Chemotherapy, commonly referred to as chemo, destroys cancer cells and stops them from growing or multiplying. Chemotherapy can be used along with radiation therapy, surgery, or both.

How is chemotherapy given?

You may be treated in your doctor’s office, a clinic in the hospital, or at home. Some common methods include:

  • Intravenous (through your veins)
  • Oral (by mouth)
  • Intramuscular (injected deep into the muscle)
  • Intrathecal (injected into the spinal canal)

Sometimes, a more permanent catheter type is recommended to avoid repeated painful needle sticks into your vein. These permanent catheters are called “central venous catheters” and are placed under your skin’s surface. Chemotherapy, blood, and IV fluids can be given through this catheter, and blood for lab tests can be drawn from this site.

An implantable port can also be used to deliver chemotherapy. It’s round in shape and is usually surgically inserted under your skin surface on the chest wall between your neck and shoulder. To use the port, the nurse will insert a needle through your skin surface to access it.

How long does chemotherapy treatment last?

Your dosage schedule is individualized to your treatment plan. This may last a few weeks, up to a year, or longer with varying cycle frequency. Treatments can be once a week, once a month, or other intervals. Treatments are followed by rest cycles to give your body time to build healthy new cells and regain strength.

What are the side effects of chemotherapy?

Common side effects may include:

  • Fatigue
  • Infections
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Hair loss
  • Anxiety, fear, anger, and depression due to life stress and chemotherapy’s effects on your mood
  • Mouth and throat sores
  • Anemia

Your potential side effects will depend on your drugs and dosages used to treat your cancer. Your doctor will prepare you for these side effects and recommend ways to cope and manage them including:

  • Nutrition for managing fatigue and nausea
  • Emotional support
  • Opportunities to discuss your unique experience and explore complimentary therapies
  • Resources for and information about hair loss
  • Infection control and education

About the Child Life Program

The Child Life program at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital seeks to support children and families coping with the emotional impact of childhood illness. We help your child understand and cope with his or her illness, and adjust to our hospital environment.

Our team consists of certified Child Life Specialists, a music therapist, a certified teacher, and technology support staff focused on reducing stress for you and your child.

Comprehensive Care and Support for Your Child

A cancer diagnosis can turn a family’s world upside down. You have questions and need answers fast. You need doctors with compassion and expertise.

At ProMedica, our goal is to find the best treatment for your child. Our Debbie Brass Children’s Cancer Center is part of the ProMedica Cancer Institute. This means you’ll have access to skilled specialists, the latest technology and the newest therapy choices.

Your ProMedica team will be with your family for every part of the cancer journey. From diagnosis to treatment to recovery — we’ll be here to support you when you need it most.

content.articleContent:
Here to Help You Prevent, Treat and Heal

Every year, more than 12,000 women in the United States are diagnosed with cervical cancer. The disease impacts a woman’s reproductive and overall health.

But the good news is that it can be prevented. It’s highly treatable when caught in its earliest stages.

You can have confidence in the women’s health and cervical cancer experts at the ProMedica Cancer Institute. They’re committed to personal, compassionate care for you.

You’ll have access to the most current research and technology in cervical cancer screening and treatment. With convenient locations across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, it’s our mission to help you achieve your best possible outcome — close to home.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Chromosomal Abnormalities

Chromosomal abnormalities onset as soon as a baby starts developing in the mother’s womb. Chromosomes (small “groups” of genes) in the body determine how a baby grows and functions after birth. Minor changes in these genes can greatly affect body and brain development.

Down Syndrome

Down syndrome affects about 1 out of every 700 babies born. The condition occurs when a baby develops in the womb with one extra copy of chromosome 21.

Down syndrome is normally tested for during pregnancy, or right after birth, to allow parents time to prepare for a baby requiring special needs.

While people with Down syndrome share similar physical traits, each individual has different abilities. They typically experience intellectual and physical challenges, but can reach full and productive lives with the support of speech, occupational and physical therapy.

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)

FAS can occur when a pregnant mother drinks alcohol, passing it through the umbilical cord to their baby.

Alcohol exposure can prevent a baby from developing properly in the womb. There is no measure for a “safe” amount of alcohol to drink during pregnancy. Zero consumption is recommended.

Children born with FAS may have abnormal facial features, experience stunted growth and central nervous system problems. In addition, many people experience trouble with learning, speech, sight, and hearing throughout their lives.

There is no cure for FAS, but early treatment and ongoing support can help a child reach their full potential.

Treatment factors:

  • Early diagnosis (before age 6)
  • Stable home environment
  • Absence of violence
  • Special education and social services

Our multidisciplinary team of physicians and behavioral health specialists can help your child reach their individual potential.

content.articleContent:
About Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or COPD, is a group of lung diseases that worsen over time and cause increasing breathlessness. COPD is the third leading cause of death for men and women in the United States. And, although 90% of people who have COPD have smoked, it can also occur from long-term contact with harmful pollutants or genetic factors.

Symptoms

If you suffer from COPD, you may experience the following symptoms:

  • Shortness of breath
  • Coughing and mucus production
  • Limited ability to complete normal activities

Diagnosing COPD

COPD is diagnosed by a doctor. Your doctor will perform a health history and physical exam. They may order additional tests including: blood work; chest X-ray; and pulmonary function test.

Treating COPD

Your treatment depends on how serious your disease. Common treatments include:

  • Knowing your symptoms and when to take action
  • Medicine (inhalers, nebulizers and oxygen therapy)
  • Stopping smoking
  • Monitoring your symptoms and taking action
  • Exercise and regular activity
  • Healthy eating

ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic

If you have trouble controlling your COPD flare ups, you may benefit from the ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic for additional education. Our team of respiratory therapists will work with you and your physician to help you better manage your disease and enjoy a better quality of life.

What services are provided at the ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic?

Your respiratory therapist will:

  • Teach you how your medications work.
  • Show you how to use your inhaler. Teach you proper breathing techniques.
  • Work with your primary care physician to carefully adjust medications, when needed.
  • Make recommendations to improve your treatment plan, if needed.

Helping You Live Your Best Life

If you’ve been diagnosed with colon or rectal cancer or think you’re at higher risk for the disease, you want to know you’re in expert hands. At ProMedica, we offer screenings, diagnoses and state-of-the-art treatments for total colorectal health.

Our specialists are highly experienced in finding colorectal cancer early, which gives you the best chance for a successful outcome. We take the time to learn about you and your lifestyle before we recommend treatments. This helps us choose the therapies that will be least disruptive to your quality of life.

content.articleContent:
About Cardiac Arrest

You may have heard the heart term cardiac arrest. But, do you know what cardiac arrest is and what to do if you see someone suddenly collapse?

Cardiac arrest occurs when electrical impulses in your heart become abnormal and your heart suddenly stops beating.

Call 911 at the first sign of any heart attack symptoms. Don't hesitate. Every second counts.

content.articleContent:
You're Never Alone During Your Fight Against Cancer

Cancer affects more than your physical health: It can also take a huge toll on your emotional and mental well-being. During treatment, and even well beyond, you may not feel like yourself. That’s why it’s essential to have support as you face the challenges of cancer treatment.

This support can and should come from many places, including your family, friends and care team here at ProMedica. Having a network of people walking beside you on this journey will help you face the future with hope and optimism.

Remember, you’re never alone during your fight against cancer. Along with your personal network, we can connect you to support groups and community resources. We also have a whole team of counselors, social workers and other providers ready to meet your unique needs.

You listened and offered encouragement.Lorraine M.

Strengthen Your Heart with Cardiac Rehab

Live longer, live stronger, and lessen your chance for another cardiac event. Our cardiac rehab program is designed to reduce your risk of other complications so you can live an active and normal life within the limits of your disease.

With cardiac rehab you can:

  • Increase your energy level and spirits
  • Learn how to exercise safely
  • Resume normal activities safely
  • Understand how to recognize symptoms of heart problems
  • Manage stress to improve your heart health
  • Adjust your lifestyle to decrease risks for future heart problems
  • Boost you and your loved ones’ confidence
  • Decrease anxiety about managing heart problems
  • Quit smoking to decrease risks of heart problems
  • Learn how to eat heart healthy

More About Cardiac Rehabilitation

If you have a heart condition, your healthcare provider may recommend a cardiac rehab program to help you recover.

Who should participate in a cardiac rehab program?

Talk to your doctor if you have or have had:

  • Stable angina
  • Heart attack
  • Open heart surgery such as coronary bypass or heart valve surgery
  • Angioplasty
  • Stent replacement
  • Heart transplant
  • Heart failure

What is included in a cardiac rehab plan?

A team of experienced professionals will help you develop an individualized care plan. Your plan will include:

  • Initial health assessment by an experienced cardiac rehab staff member
  • Pre- and post-functional exercise evaluation
  • Personalized exercise program
  • Continuous EKG heart-monitored exercise sessions
  • Individualized risk factor modification
  • Ongoing contact with physicians involved in your care
  • Individual and group education and support
  • Discharge evaluation and recommendations

Understanding Cardio-Oncology

As part of your cancer care, you may be given drugs or radiation treatment to kill cancer cells. Sometimes the normal cells in and around your heart may also be harmed, causing lasting damage. This is called cardio toxicity. Your risk increases if you already have heart disease.

The cardio-oncology program at ProMedica Cancer Institute balances these risks. Our team of cardiologists and hematologists/oncologists work with you and your primary care provider to lessen the cardio toxicity that may be caused by your cancer treatment.

Cardio-oncology is appropriate at any stage of your cancer treatment or survivorship journey. Sometimes heart issues may surface long after cancer treatment is complete.

Do you need a cardio-oncology evaluation?

Your doctor bases your need for a cardio-oncology evaluation on:

  • The type of cancer you have
  • The cancer treatment plan developed for your cancer
  • Your current and past heart health
  • Any changes in your heart health during or any time after treatment – even years after your treatment completion

For more information, call ProMedica Cancer Institute at 877-291-1441. Ask for the cardio-oncology clinic.

What happens at a cardio-oncology clinic appointment?

You’ll see a cardiologist in our clinic, located in ProMedica Hickman Cancer Center, a department of ProMedica Toledo Hospital, on the campus of ProMedica Flower Hospital in Sylvania, Ohio. The cardiologist will review your heart function and health history (such as age, gender, BMI, and history of heart conditions).

The doctor may order special tests including cardiac-specific blood tests and an echocardiogram with strain imaging. The echocardiogram, a special cardiac ultrasound, evaluates the function of your heart muscle.

After the evaluation, the cardiologist, if needed, may:

  • Prescribe drugs or treatments to help protect your heart during your cancer treatment.
  • Develop a plan to monitor and improve your heart health following cancer treatment – which may include additional visits to the cardio-oncology clinic.
  • Work with your oncologist to adjust your cancer treatment to lessen harmful effects to your heart.

Please know: We will not delay your cancer treatment. As always, your treatment will begin as soon as possible.

How to make an appointment

  • Talk with your oncologist or primary care provider to decide if you are a candidate for the cardio-oncology clinic.
  • Call ProMedica Cancer Institute at 877-291-1441. Ask for the cardio-oncology clinic.

content.articleContent:
Nationally Recognized Heart Surgery Close to Home

When you or a loved one needs heart surgery, you want expert care and the comforts of home. We believe you should have both, because home is where your heart should be. Experience nationally-recognized heart surgery close to home.

Our highly distinguished heart surgeons provide nationally recognized care right here in northwest Ohio. Our team performs more cardiothoracic surgeries than any other group in the region – more than 900 surgeries every year. We use state-of-the-art technology and surgical techniques for improved patient outcomes and we work hard to keep you close to home for diagnosis, treatment, recovery and follow-up.

Our team of cardiothoracic surgeons has earned national recognition from organizations like U.S. News & World Report, The Society of Thoracic Surgeons and other hospital rating and ranking organizations.

Advanced Care for Cystic Fibrosis

Cystic fibrosis is a disease that primarily affects the lungs and pancreas, but impacts the entire body. While no cure currently exists, tremendous treatment developments now allow you or your loved one to live well into adulthood. Here you’ll find the care you need, at any age, from diagnosis to ongoing treatment and research.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is cystic fibrosis?

Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disease where the body creates an unusually thick, sticky mucus. The abnormal mucus clogs the lungs, causing infections and making it difficult to breathe. This mucous also prevents the pancreas from secreting the digestive enzymes produced. Without these enzymes, it’s hard for the body to absorb enough nutrients. Physical growth can be affected.

Symptoms include:

  • Salty tasting skin
  • Persistent cough, sometimes with phlegm
  • Frequent lung infections
  • Shortness of breath or wheezing
  • Slow growth and weight gain, in spite of eating well
  • Frequent bowel movements that may be greasy and bulky

Talk to your primary care physician right away if you or your child has any of these symptoms. Early treatment can help reduce the impact of this disease.

How is cystic fibrosis diagnosed?

Children are typically diagnosed before two years of age. Diagnosis occurs in several ways:

  • Newborn infant screening at birth (all children born in the U.S. are screened)
  • Sweat chloride test
  • Genetic testing
  • Chest X-rays and lung function testing
  • Stool sample analysis

Learn about sweat chloride testing

How is cystic fibrosis treated?

Cystic fibrosis treatment eases your, or your child’s, symptoms and improves quality of life. This disease affects individuals differently, so the treatment plan is tailored to you or your child.

Common treatments include:

  • Airway Clearing Techniques help you clear the thick mucus from your lungs.
  • Inhaled medicines (bronchodilators or antibiotics) are turned into a mist and inhaled.
  • Pancreatic enzymes capsules are taken before meals and snacks to aid with digestion.

Treating Cystic Fibrosis in Adults

Cystic Fibrosis is potentially life-threatening. But recent progress in treatments has more than doubled the life expectancy for those living with cystic fibrosis. Our treatments are state-of-the-art and based on the latest research and standards. You’ll get the expert care you need to keep going strong.

The Cystic Fibrosis Center of Northwest Ohio

Receive the latest, most advanced care at our nationally accredited Cystic Fibrosis Center of Northwest Ohio. Our accreditation with the National Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (CFF) ensures that you or your loved one is receiving comprehensive state-of-the-art care, as strict evidence-based guidelines are followed. Our care center is also a part of the Therapeutic Drug Network through the CFF, which permits cutting edge research in cystic fibrosis to occur right here in northwest Ohio. You’ll get everything you need to treat this disease.

Learn More

content.articleContent:
Understand CT, commonly known as a CAT Scan

You want to know what to expect, what it is, and why it may benefit your healt; we’ll help with that.

What is a CT? Short for computed tomography, a CT is a series of X-rays taken from different angles of targeted body parts. Compiling these X-rays into images gives your radiologist essential information about your bones or your body’s soft tissues.

Why is a CT performed? CT is requested for many reasons. Your doctor may want further information to:
  • Locate an infection, a blood clot, or a tumor.
  • Diagnose muscle or bone issues.
  • Detect internal injuries.
  • Diagnose and monitor heart, lung, or liver disease.
  • Guide surgical, biopsy, or radiology procedures.
  • Detect lung cancer

How does CT work? During your CT, you’ll lie down and pass slowly through a large, doughnut-shaped machine. You’ll be able to communicate with your technician the entire time, but will need to remain still during the test. During this time, the CT machine takes various X-rays that your radiologist will interpret. At a later appointment, your doctor will discuss with you your results.

Why is a CT important to my health? CT gives your doctor valuable insight into your body, how it’s functioning, and what treatments may result. The more accurate your diagnosis, the more effective your treatment.

locations.name: PROMEDICA CHARLES AND VIRGINIA HICKMAN HOSPITAL

content.articleContent:
Understanding Deep Vein Thrombosis

Veins carry blood back up through your body. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) happened when a clot (thrombus) forms in a deep vein, usually in your leg.

DVT is a dangerous condition. If the clot breaks free from the wall of your vein and is released into your bloodstream, it’s called an embolus. This embolus can travel through your bloodstream and up to your lungs. There, it can block your blood vessel and the lung’s blood supply.

The resulting condition is called a pulmonary embolism and can be fatal.

Understanding Depression

Major depression is a chronic condition and different than just experiencing the occasional “blues”. If you have depression, it consistently affects your mood, thoughts and body.

Symptoms of Depression

You may notice several of the following signs during the same two-week period:

  • Difficulty with relationships
  • Excessive guilt
  • Hopelessness
  • Extremely sensitive to failure or rejection
  • Unable to concentrate
  • Lack energy
  • Lack interest in activities once enjoyed
  • Persistent sadness
  • Irritability, hostility, or aggression
  • Feeling of wanting to die
  • Changes in appetite or weight
  • Low self-esteem
  • Sleeping too much or very little
  • Thinking about suicide or attempting suicide

In most cases, treatment is necessary for recovery. Begin a conversation about your depression with your primary care physician, or look for a behavioral health specialist such as a counselor or psychiatrist.

Depression in Children and Adolescents

According to the National Institute of Mental Health, the onset of major depression is occurring much earlier in life than it used to. And the earlier the condition onsets, the higher the probability that it will continue into adulthood.

If your adolescent has major depression, they are unable to merely “snap out of it” and feel better on their own.

What should you do if your think your child has major depression? Contact your pediatrician or family doctor immediately to discuss. Early diagnosis of depression is important because it often coexists with another psychiatric disorder, such as substance abuse or anxiety disorder. If your doctor feels your child needs further assessment, they may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. Major depression can be effectively treated.

locations.imageAlt: ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital
locations.name: PROMEDICA RUSSELL J. EBEID CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL

content.articleContent:
Understanding DEXA Scans

You’ve discussed a DEXA or bone density scan with your doctor and want to know more. Feel confident understanding what to expect and how it works.

What is a bone scan?

It’s an important way to see if a disease has developed in your bones. It functions much like a standard X-ray, but differs in that a radioactive material is injected into your body. This material settles into your bones for a short time and allows your doctor to detect bone disease much earlier than when using typical X-ray.

It’s a comfortable procedure that takes about three to four hours, which includes time for the injected material to settle and for the actual scan (X-ray).

Why is a bone scan important to your health?

A bone scan is an important tool to quickly detect the source of various symptoms you may have experienced like bone pain or swelling. Early detection is essential to prevent fractures or the spread of disease or infection through your bones. You and your doctor can discuss the most effective treatments based on your bone scan results.

locations.imageAlt: ProMedica Bay Park Hospital - Women's Center
locations.name: PROMEDICA BAY PARK HOSPITAL - WOMEN'S CENTER

content.articleContent:
Take Charge of Your Diabetes

A diabetes diagnosis can change the way you approach your day-to-day life. You may be an adult who’s been diagnosed. Or perhaps you’re caring for a child with diabetes. In every case it’s important to understand how the disease works, how to manage it and where you can get diabetes support.

The number of Americans living with diabetes grows every year. That’s why at ProMedica, we believe it’s important to do our part to help people take charge of their own health after a diabetes diagnosis.

If you suspect you or your child might have diabetes, contact your ProMedica doctor right away. We’ll review your symptoms and risk factors, and run diagnostic tests to pinpoint the reason for your symptoms.

Together, we’ll take charge.

content.articleContent:
About Diabetic Retinopathy

Diabetic eye disease refers to a group of eye problems that people with diabetes could face. These conditions may include diabetic retinopathy, cataracts and glaucoma. Although eye diseases can cause severe vision loss or even blindness, they can often be treated before vision loss occurs. Prevention is the key.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is diabetic retinopathy?

Diabetic retinopathy is the most common eye disease in people with diabetes and is a leading cause of blindness in American adults. Changes in the blood vessels of the retina, the light sensitive layer of tissue at the back of the inner eye, can lead to this condition. In some people, retinal blood vessels may swell and leak fluid. In others, abnormal new blood vessels grow on the surface of the retina. These changes may result in vision loss or blindness.

Who is at risk for diabetic retinopathy?

Anyone with diabetes is at risk for diabetic retinopathy. The longer you have diabetes, the more likely you are to develop diabetic retinopathy. Your risk rises if you have diabetes and you smoke, have high blood pressure, or are pregnant.

What are the symptoms of diabetic retinopathy?

In the early stages of diabetic retinopathy, you may have no symptoms. Vision may not change until the disease gets worse. Then you may have blurry or double vision; dark or floating spots; pain or pressure in one or both eyes; or rings, flashing lights, or blank spots in your vision.

A decrease in your central vision could be caused by macular edema which may occur from diabetic retinopathy. It happens when the macula, a part of the retina, swells from the leaking fluid and causes blurred vision. When new vessels grow on the surface of the retina, they can bleed into the eye. This may decrease vision.

How is diabetic retinopathy diagnosed?

Along with a complete health history and eye exam, your eye care professional may do these tests to diagnose diabetic retinopathy:

  • Visual acuity test. This is the common eye chart test that measures vision ability at various distances.
  • Tonometry. This standard test is done to check the pressure (intraocular pressure, or IOP) inside the eye.
  • Pupil dilation. For a close up exam of the eye’s lens and retina, your pupil is widened with eye drops.
  • Ophthalmoscopy. This is a test where a doctor looks very closely at the retina using a special magnifying glass.
  • Fluorescein angiography. In this test, a dye is injected into the bloodstream. The dye helps the blood vessels in the eye show up while pictures are taken with a special camera. This test lets the doctor see if the blood vessels are leaking.
  • Optical coherence tomography. In this test, light waves are used to make detailed images of the retina.

How is diabetic retinopathy treated?

If you have diabetic retinopathy, your treatment will depend on your age, general health, symptoms and the severity of the condition.

Even people with advanced retinopathy have a good chance of keeping their vision if they are treated before the retina becomes severely damaged. Treatment for diabetic retinopathy may include:

  • Laser surgery. This involves shrinking the abnormal blood vessels, or sealing the leaking ones.
  • Vitrectomy. Vitrectomy is a procedure that involves removing the cloudy, jelly-like substance (vitreous) that fills the center of the eye. The vitreous is replaced with a saline solution.
  • Injections. Certain medications can be injected into the eye to slow the growth of the abnormal vessels of the retina.

Can diabetic retinopathy be prevented?

While you can’t completely prevent diabetic retinopathy, you can reduce your risk of getting it. Controlling your blood sugar slows the start of retinopathy and keeps it from getting worse. It also lessens the need for laser surgery for severe retinopathy.

You can reduce the risk of developing the condition by:

  • Having a dilated eye exam once a year. An eye exam does not prevent retinopathy but it can help diagnose eye problems that can then be treated. An eye exam can also alert you and your healthcare provider if the diabetes needs to be better controlled.
  • Having an eye exam before pregnancy or in the first trimester of your pregnancy. If you’re pregnant and take insulin to manage your diabetes, that can raise the odds that the condition will become worse. Continue to be monitored every trimester and for 1 year after birth depending on how severe the retinopathy is.

Treating ENT Problems for Your Best Health

We’ve all experienced ear, nose and throat (ENT) problems at one time or another. Whether you have common or chronic ENT conditions, ProMedica ENT physicians can help you manage and overcome them. This team of board-certified otolaryngologists wants to see you get back to living the life you love.

Live the Life You Love Without Missing a Beat

An irregular heartbeat, known as arrhythmia, can happen suddenly and take you by surprise. It can be scary, too. That’s why it’s important to act quickly and work with a team you trust to understand your condition. ProMedica’s electrophysiologists offer specialized arrhythmia care in Toledo. They assess, diagnose and treat irregular heart rhythm problems, including atrial fibrillation (AFib). ProMedica cares about your peace of mind. That’s why we offer you high-quality, best-in-class care close to home.

A Closer Look with Your Comfort in Mind

Sometimes your doctor needs to take a closer look to make an accurate diagnosis. With endoscopy services at ProMedica locations all around the Toledo metro area, you won’t have to go far for your procedure. Whether you choose one of our area hospitals or an outpatient location, you can feel safe and at ease knowing you’ll be in the capable, gentle care of the ProMedica team.

A Clear View for Healthy Eyesight

Eyesight is one of our most valuable senses. That’s why ProMedica offers complete, full-service ophthalmology services for patients of every age all around northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. From routine vision testing, glasses and contact lenses to eye disorder treatment and even vision correction, we’re all about meeting your every eye-care need.

content.articleContent:
Helping Children See the World Clearly

Children’s bodies grow and change fast — and that includes their eyes. That’s why it’s important for children to get regular eye care. ProMedica’ eye care team can make sure their eyes are healthy and detect and correct eye problems in their early stages.

We recommend that infants be closely checked by their pediatrician and have their first eye exam when they’re six months old. Children should have more eye exams when they enter preschool at age three and before they start kindergarten at age five or six. School age children should visit an eye doctor for a complete vision screening every one to two years.

Common pediatric eye conditions include:

  • Amblyopia (lazy eye).
  • Blocked tear duct.
  • Cataract (cloudy eyes).
  • Cellulitis (an infection of the eyelid that’s related to trauma or an upper respiratory problem).
  • Chalazion (small lump on the eyelid).
  • Conjunctivitis (pink eye).
  • Juvenile macular degeneration.
  • Pediatric glaucoma.
  • Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid).
  • Sty (a red, sore lump near the edge of the eyelid).

Exercise Your Way to Lifelong Health

Whether you want to get back in shape after baby, need to regain strength after an orthopaedic injury or are managing a health condition like heart disease or diabetes, an exercise plan can help you reach your fitness goals.

From better sleep to a more confident you, exercise offers you many benefits including:

  • Improved heart, lung, bone and joint health.
  • Reduced risk for future injury, heart disease, high blood pressure and some cancers.
  • Lower stress levels.
  • Weight management and weight loss.

ProMedica offers a variety of exercise programs designed to meet a variety of health goals. And, our trainers, medical exercise specialists and nutritionists are on hand to guide every step of your journey.

About Gynecologic Surgery

Treatment for a number of female reproductive conditions may require surgery. We help you get back on your feet and back to your normal activities faster with robotic surgery.

Robotic Surgery

Gynecologic robotic surgery is performed through several tiny incisions, making robotic surgery the least invasive type of gynecologic surgery available.

Gynecologic surgeries we perform with the da Vinci® Surgical System include:

  • Cervical cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Benign hysterectomy
  • Hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopy diagnostic
  • Myomectomy
  • Oophorectomy
  • Pelvic reconstruction
  • Pelvic pain procedures
  • Resection of endometriosis
  • Sacrocolpopexy

If your physician recommends surgery for any of these conditions, ask if robotic surgery is right for you. Robotic surgery is available at ProMedica Bay Park Hospital, ProMedica Flower Hospital, and ProMedica Toledo Hospital.

Call 419-291-4575 to learn more about gynecologic robotic surgery.

Personalized care for you and your daughter

A woman’s health care needs can be very personal. You need a provider you can trust to ask the right questions, provide the best treatments and offer you choices that fit your life and your health.

At ProMedica, our gynecologists focus on your specific needs. From puberty on, we’re here for you with the full range of gynecologic care, individualized for your age, your health and your personal choices.

We’re also here for your daughter, with advice on how to talk with her about safe sex and also with immunizations to protect her from sexually transmitted diseases. We want you and your daughter to stay as healthy as you can be.

Boost Your Healing

If you’re dealing with slow-healing wounds, diabetic foot ulcers or serious burns, it can be hard to focus on the rest of your health. When you need help, you can count on ProMedica for state-of-the-art hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBO) and healing.

For medical emergency referrals, call 919-684-4326. Ask to speak to the HBO physician on call. Diving emergency referrals should contact Divers Alert Network at 800-446-2671.

Advanced Cardiac Care from a Compassionate Team

Your heart works hard for you. And when it’s healthy, it gives you the strength you need for activities that bring you joy.

At the ProMedica Heart Institute, it’s our mission to help you live your very best life. You can count on our heart team for compassion, expertise and the most advanced technologies available — all so you can benefit from the very best in cardiac care.

Learn more about heart services.

View our 2021 annual report

If you think you or someone you’re with is having a heart attack, call 911.

Understanding Heart Disease

Heart disease, also called cardiovascular disease, is a phrase used to describe a number of different diseases of the heart like:

  • Irregular heartbeat
  • Congenital (birth) heart defects
  • Weak heart muscles
  • Heart valve problems
  • Heart infections
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Heart attack
  • Heart failure
  • Stroke

Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. It commonly leads to heart failure and heart attack. But what causes it, and how do you know your risks?

Are You at Risk for Heart Disease?

  • Do you have diabetes?
  • Is your blood pressure high?
  • Have you been tested for high cholesterol?
  • Do you smoke?
  • Are you overweight?
  • Are you inactive?
  • Is there a family history of heart disease?
  • Are your stress levels high?

ProMedica Physicians cardiologist A. Vincent Songco MD, FACC says, “If you have diabetes, high blood pressure or high cholesterol, your main goal is to keep your number(s) within normal limits. If you're having trouble, your doctor may prescribe medications.” Ask your doctor what numbers are healthy for you.

Lower Your Risk of Heart Disease

Fortunately, many heart diseases are within your control. With the help of your doctor, you can make changes in your lifestyle to improve your heart health and minimize the risk of heart disease.

To lower your risk for heart disease:

  • Maintain a healthy weight. Discuss with your doctor what is healthy for you.
  • Increase your physical activity. Your doctor can guide you on beginning an exercise program.
  • Kick the habit. Find a stop smoking program to support you.
  • Limit your alcohol consumption.
  • Eat heart smart foods. Foods rich in good fats: peanuts, olive oil, oatmeal, flaxseed. And foods rich in nutrients: egg whites, berries, kale, and whole grain bread. Avoid foods high in sodium.
  • Reduce your stress. Find calming activities and spend time with supportive people.

Talk with your doctor about your lifestyle choices and how they affect your heart health. If you have concerns, explore diagnostic tests and treatments for heart disease.

When You Want the Very Best for Your Heart

If your heart is damaged from a heart attack or other heart condition, you want skilled and compassionate care. You can count on the expert team at ProMedica. Our heart surgeons use state-of-the-art technology and the most advanced surgical methods to care for one of your most vital organs.

Here to Help You Live a Healthy, Active Life

If you or a loved one have been diagnosed with hemophilia, you likely have lots of questions about your health and what lies ahead. Your ProMedica team is here to answer your questions, ease your fears and provide support and guidance every step of the way.

Hemophilia doesn’t have to slow you down. With the right treatment and expert care, you and your family can live a healthy, active lifestyle.

Protect Your Health, Know Your Numbers

High blood pressure (HBP), or hypertension, is a common form of heart disease that affects nearly half of all adults in the United States. And, since the condition offers very few warning signs, it often goes undetected in roughly one-third of those who have it.

Just knowing you have hypertension is a step in the right direction. Working together, you and your doctor can put a plan in place to manage it so you can protect your heart.

More than 100 million American adults have high blood pressure. Could you be one of them?
