content.articleContent:
We’re here for your healing heart.

A heart attack is a life-changing event. Whether it happens to you or a loved one, it’s natural to feel overwhelmed. That’s where we come in.

Our expert and compassionate team will guide your every step. From helping you understand why it happened to walking you and your family through what comes next, we’ll be by your side. Informing. Supporting. Caring.

Understanding Heart Failure

Heart failure is the condition in which your heart cannot pump sufficient blood to meet your body's needs. It is a multi-stage condition that means your heart is working less efficiently than a normal heart. You may have heard heart failure called "congestive heart failure" or "CHF."

Heart Failure and Its Problems

What’s important to know is heart failure is often long-term, and is caused by many different heart problems such as:

  • Heart disease
  • Heart attack
  • Heart valve disease
  • Abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias)
  • Infections that weaken the heart

Common Signs of Heart Failure

  • Do you have shortness of breath when you're active or after you lie down?
  • Do you have trouble breathing when you're lying down?
  • Have you gained weight?
  • Are your legs and ankles swollen?
  • Do you feel weak or tired easily?
  • Does your heart race or beat in an uneven pattern?

Heart Failure Risk Factors

  • If you have had a previous heart attack
  • Family history of heart attack
  • If you are a man over 45 or woman over 55
  • Smoking
  • High blood pressure
  • High blood cholesterol
  • Being overweight
  • Limited or no exercise
  • Diabetes

If you think you may have heart failure, talk to your doctor about diagnosis and treatment options.

About the Infant Monitor Program

Assuring the safe transportation of infants is a requirement at the time of hospital discharge, and consequently, medically fragile and/or premature infants generally undergo a car seat challenge to ensure they are physiologically ready to travel in a rear-facing car seat. Most tested (or challenged) infants will travel home from the hospital in a properly fitted car seat; however, because some infants are unable to maintain a patent airway in the semi-reclined position of a car seat, they must instead travel home in a recumbent car bed. 

We meet the needs of high-risk infants at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital with our diagnostic, therapeutic and educational Infant Monitor Program. We support infants and families whose conditions require the use of home monitoring services. Our pediatric pulmonologists are lung specialists who are board-certified in pediatrics and in pediatric pulmonary medicine with a specialty in intensive care and direct patient care. Our team of physicians, nurses and respiratory therapists follow your baby’s care.

Infants referred to the Infant Monitor Program may be:

  • Babies who experience an apparent life-threatening event (ALTE)
  • SIDS siblings
  • Premature infants with apnea / bradycardia
  • Infants with obstructive apnea
  • Babies with seizure / neurological-related apnea
  • Oxygen dependent infants
  • Infants with cardiac problems

Infants that initially fail the car seat challenge should undergo an additional car seat challenge prior to transitioning to a traditional, semi-reclined car seat. The Infant Monitor Program staff at Toledo and Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital's will administer follow-up test on infants that failed their initial Car Seat Challenge Testing prior to discharge. 

Follow-up out-patient testing is done in Harris McIntosh Tower by a Respiratory Therapist or an RN, when the pediatrician feels it is time to re-test.  A test will take a minimum of 90 minutes. 

We can be reached by telephone 24 hours a day to answer questions and solve problems related to infant alarms and/or equipment use

Contact the Infant Monitor Program at 419-291-2229 or 800-876-2763.

Quality Testing for Better Health

ProMedica Laboratories has committed to provide quality testing to improve your health and well-being. Using the latest in advanced testing, paired with expert consultation, we are able to provide continuum care across the entire ProMedica system.

When you have your medical testing performed by ProMedica Laboratories, you are receiving the highest level of quality. Certification and accreditation programs in which ProMedica Laboratories participates represent the on-going commitment to exacting quality standards.

content.articleContent:
About Lymphedema

Lymphedema refers to excessive swelling of one or more extremities following damage to the lymphatic system. The lymphatic system is a complicated system in the body that helps to carry fluid, bacteria and harmful substance through a series of lymph nodes that “clean” the fluid.

When lymph nodes are damaged or surgically removed, the system can malfunction and lead to excessive and sometimes uncontrollable swelling in the body. This can often happen as a result of cancer and the treatment associated with it. Lymphedema can be a debilitating disease that has a significant impact on the ability to perform everyday tasks.

Treating Lymphedema with ProMedica Total Rehab

How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?

If you are experiencing any of the symptoms discussed, then lymphedema therapy may be beneficial to you. ProMedica Total Rehab employs licensed and certified therapists that specialize in the treatment of this condition. Therapy will include:

  • Education on self-care
  • Techniques for reducing and controlling swelling,
  • Techniques that will help to improve day to day function.

Which ProMedica locations offer lymphedema therapy?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide lymphedema therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.

  • Please consult with your physician to determine if lymphedema therapy is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

content.articleContent:
About Mammography

You know early breast cancer detection is essential. It’s important you feel confident in the screening you receive. Talk with your doctor about digital mammography’s enhanced quality and accuracy.

How does a digital mammogram work?

As far as your experience, all mammograms are very much alike. You’ll most likely begin regular mammograms between the ages of 35 and 40, younger if there’s a breast cancer history for yourself or your family. Your mammograms are used for both early detection as well as for diagnosis of lumps, breast pain or unusual breast symptoms.

During your mammogram, your breast is compressed between two flat surfaces and X-rayed. Digital mammograms display and record the high definition X-ray images on a computer monitor, while a standard film-based mammogram records these images on individual films.

What are the benefits of digital mammography?

A few solid benefits for you are:

  • Less exposure to radiation compared to a standard film-based mammogram.
  • Reduced need for mammogram re-takes means less time spent for you
  • Higher resolution images and image manipulation for accurate detection and diagnosis
  • Your images are stored in computer files for easy access and sharing amongst experts

Is a digital mammogram right for you?

This decision is between you and your doctor, but the common perspective is that digital mammography is better suited for you if you:
  • Are under 50 years old
  • Have dense breasts
  • Haven’t been through menopause or have gone through it within the past year

Are digital mammograms available at every ProMedica Radiology location?

We have many convenient locations with this state-of-the-art technique. Find one near you.

Healthy Babies, Healthy Moms

Congratulations on your pregnancy! As you get ready for your new baby, it’s time to focus on you. On getting the best possible maternity care, and on taking extra special care of yourself.

The idea of giving birth can seem daunting. You want to know you’re in the care of a highly skilled delivery team. With ProMedica you don’t have to look far. Nearly half of the babies born in Toledo are born at ProMedica Toledo Hospital, which is also home to a Level III perinatal unit. And, we offer more high quality maternal care in our other hospitals throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.

Our obstetricians and gynecologists (OB/GYNs) and pediatricians are ready to care for your maternity needs — and your baby’s — during pregnancy, childbirth and after delivery (postpartum).

content.articleContent:
About Midwifery

ProMedica’s certified nurse midwives provide an array of women’s care services. While midwives are probably best known for their care of women during pregnancy and childbirth, they are also experts in women’s health throughout the lifespan - from adolescence through menopause.

Midwives offer specialized care, intended to foster a holistic approach to health and well-being, by providing choices of healthcare options that help their patients make informed decisions.

Midwifery services include:

  • Menopause management
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Prenatal care and birth
  • Family planning
  • Pelvic pain
  • Well-woman care

content.articleContent:
Understanding High-Risk Pregnancy

Often, pregnancies have little or no complications. But if you or your baby are considered high-risk, you’ll get expert care from our multi-disciplinary team of maternal-fetal medicine specialists.

You might be considered high risk as the result of a medical condition you had before you become pregnant. Or your pregnancy can become high risk if a medical condition develops during your pregnancy for either you or your baby.

Complications that lead to high risk include:

  • Hypertension (high blood pressure)
  • Diabetes
  • Rh disease
  • Multiple gestation including twins of higher multiples
  • Platelet and blood disorder including thrombocytopenia, sickle cell anemia, and thalassemia
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss, including incompetent cervix
  • Fetal abnormalities, including growth disorders, inherited disease, and structural malformations
  • Abnormal bleeding
  • Cardiac problems
  • Trauma

The Risk of Preterm Labor

Some of these complications can lead to preterm labor. Learn the signs of preterm labor, and talk to your obstetrician if you have concerns.

Download this brochure to learn more about preterm labor

Care for High-Risk Pregnancies

Care begins with evaluation and consultation to identify risks and potential treatment options. Diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, such as amniocentesis, chorionic villus samples, and umbilical cord blood samples may be performed. When appropriate, these services are also available:

  • 3D/4D ultrasound
  • Genetic diagnosis and ultrasound
  • Fetal therapy
  • Prevention and management of prematurity
  • Transportation of high-risk maternity patients and newborns via helicopter equipped with mobile ICUs
  • Pregnancy loss evaluation and treatment
  • Perinatal hospice program

Your Care Team

Your care is co-managed by our board-certified maternal-fetal medicine physicians along with your Ob/Gyn and our multidisciplinary team. This team includes:

  • Maternal-fetal medicine specialized nurses
  • Genetic counselors
  • Certified diabetic educators
  • Dietitians and nutritionists

You’ll also have access to:

  • Certified nurse midwives
  • A perinatal social worker
  • Neonatologists
  • Lactation consultants
  • Respiratory therapists
  • Parent instructors

Ask your obstetrician to refer you to Maternal-Fetal Medicine at ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Or call us at 419-291-3604 to learn more.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Your Body Through Menopause

Menopause is a natural biological process, but it can sometimes cause unwanted symptoms. If you’re experiencing hot flashes, sleep problems, thinning hair or other issues, your OB/Gyn can help you manage your symptoms with lifestyle changes or treatments. ProMedica’s menopause clinic is also ready to help with specialized menopause management.

About Molecular Breast Imaging (MBI)

You want an accurate reading of your breast health. If you have dense breast tissue, molecular breast imaging (MBI) can supplement your mammogram.

ProMedica Breast Care is one of the only locations in the Midwest where you’ll find new MBI technology at work.

Understanding MRI

In order to diagnose a disease or confirm your treatment’s effectiveness, your doctor sometimes needs high-resolution images of your organs or other parts of your body. To get these images, your doctor may order an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan.

How does MRI work?

MRI is a technique that uses radio waves and a magnetic field to gather these necessary images. During an MRI, you’ll lie inside an MRI machine (in most cases). It’s here that the magnetic field inside the machine will re-align itself with your body and, paired with radio waves, will give off faint signals.

Your radiology technician or nurse will record the signals and images and report them to your radiologist who, in turn, will interpret the findings. These findings help with diagnosis and treatment recommendations.

Where do you go for your MRI?

Choose from our many radiology centers offering MRI, as well as a variety of other radiology services.

About Multiple Sclerosis

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease in which your immune system attacks myelin, the covering that protects your nerves. This damage to the myelin disrupts information flow both within your brain and between your brain and the rest of your body. These nerves deteriorate, which is an irreversible condition. MS is a degenerative disease, meaning the symptoms will get progressively worse over time.

MS Symptoms

People with multiple sclerosis usually have their first symptoms between the ages of 20 and 40. Signs and symptoms vary depending on the extent of nerve damage and which nerves are affected. Some Multiple Sclerosis symptoms include:

  • Blurred vision
  • Loss of balance
  • Poor coordination
  • Slurred speech
  • Tremors
  • Numbness
  • Extreme fatigue
  • Problems with memory and concentration
  • Paralysis
  • Blindness

MS Flare-Ups

You can go days or years without major changes in your symptoms and then suddenly experience a “flare up,” or relapse. MS is active again when you develop new MS symptoms, a regular problem gets worse, or your symptoms last 24 hours or longer.

Causes of Multiple Sclerosis

The cause of MS is currently unknown, but childhood infections and genetics are believed to play a role.There’s no cure, but there are ways to control your symptoms. Since prolonged over-exertion and stress may be contributing factors to flare ups, exercise, regular stretching, and relaxation may help you manage MS symptoms. Talk to your primary physician or neurologist, who may recommend treatments such as physical therapy, muscle relaxants, or medications to reduce fatigue or other symptoms.

Responsive, Nurturing Care for Babies and Their Families

When your newborn needs swift, precise attention, the highly trained team at the Hillabrand Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital is here with around-the-clock care. You can count on us to be sensitive to your fragile newborn’s unique needs, and your concerns.

Neurologic Rehabilitation at ProMedica

You want rehabilitation professionals skilled in neurology.

Our neurological rehab addresses the physical, emotional, and psychological needs of each patient. We evaluate movement patterns, strength, flexibility, functional ability, balance, and muscle tone. Our team addresses various functional areas such as:

  • Thinking skills
  • Communication skills
  • Walking
  • Use of hands and arms
  • Daily living activities

We offer a range of physical, occupational, and speech therapies in a variety of settings, such as:

  • Acute care
  • Inpatient rehab
  • Outpatient rehab
  • Schools
  • Skilled nursing facilities

Begin your journey to health. Search for a neurological rehabilitation location near you, or download this list of neurological rehab locations.

Ease Your Mind

ProMedica's award-winning team of neurology experts includes board-certified neurologists and neurosurgeons. Whether your treatment starts at a ProMedica hospital, doctor’s office or outpatient facility, you’ll benefit from our coordinated, expert neurological care.

We’re here to help you live better when you’re facing a neurological condition. And we’re ready to guide you through the basics and beyond.

Learn more about our neurology and neurosurgery services.

View our 2021 annual report

Neurosurgery at ProMedica Toledo Hospital

Receive best-in-class neurosurgery care right here at ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Our experienced team of neurosurgeons brings a long-standing history of quality care and expertise in the diagnosis and surgical treatment of brain and spine conditions. As part of ProMedica Neurosciences Institute, Toledo Hospital connects you to the latest neurosurgery technologies, treatments, resources and experts.

BrightMatter™ Technology

Toledo Hospital is home to Ohio’s first BrightMatter™ technology, an innovative solution that combines advanced imaging, planning, navigation and robotics for complex brain and spine surgeries. BrightMatter provides our neurosurgeons with the latest advancements in visualization tools to perform minimally invasive, patient-specific brain and spine procedures. It uses an advanced MRI brain-imaging method called diffusion tensor imaging, or DTI, to create a highly detailed map of the brain’s white matter pathways. This functionality allows surgeons to see details that can't be seen with the naked eye and may allow access to brain locations previously deemed inoperable.

 
 
 

BrightMatter leads to less surgical time and improved patient outcomes.

Conditions and diseases treated:

  • Aneurysms
  • Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs)
  • Brain tumors
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Degenerative diseases
  • Infections
  • Injuries and trauma
  • Spine and spinal cord conditions

Types of procedures performed:

  • Craniectomy
  • Craniotomy
  • Discectomy
  • Laminectomy
  • Skull base surgery
  • Spinal fusion

Call 419-291-4590 today to schedule an appointment with a neurosurgeon.

Understanding Nuclear Medicine

Nuclear medicine is used to determine how an organ is functioning. For example, nuclear medicine can be used to study how a damaged heart is functioning or how blood flow is restricted in parts of the brain. Other organs that can be imaged using nuclear medicine include the liver, kidneys, thyroid, bones, and many others.

During a nuclear medicine study, chemicals "tagged" with radionuclides that emit gamma rays are injected into the body. The chemicals collect in the area of the body that is to be studied. Images, which may be taken immediately or days after the injection, are obtained by using a gamma camera that detects the gamma rays and produces an image map called a scintigram.

Nuclear medicine studies provide information that can help your doctor diagnose and treat diseases in their early stages. Nuclear medicine, using radioactive substances, can also be used to treat certain diseases and conditions, such as overactive thyroid glands or thyroid tumors.

Preparing for a Nuclear Medicine Study

Generally, there are no special preparations that need to be made prior to having a nuclear medicine study. However, certain types of studies may require some preparation. For example, prior to having a thyroid uptake and scan, your doctor may ask that you avoid foods and medications with iodine for one week prior to the test. Your doctor or radiologist can advise you about any special instructions you may need to follow.

Reap the Lifetime Benefits of Better Nutrition

You want to eat a balanced, nutritious diet. But what does that mean? The answer is unique to you. One-on-one time with a registered dietitian will help you plan and reach your nutritional goals.

Call us at 419-291-6767 to schedule an appointment with a registered dietitian.

Nutrition Counseling FAQ

What is nutrition counseling?

Learn the value of a balanced, nutrition diet from our certified nutrition specialists.

  • Assessment of nutrition history and specific nutrient needs
  • Nutrient analysis of a specific three-day food record
  • Individual menu plan
  • Goal setting
  • Diet navigation
  • Recommended meal planning apps

How will nutrition counseling help you?

This program is tailored to your specific needs, potentially including:

  • Weight management
  • Nutrition after surgery or illness
  • Food allergy management
  • Health risk minimization and disease prevention

What does nutrition counseling cost?

Program costs may be reimbursed by health care flexible spending accounts. Contact us at 419-291-6767 for information.

How do you get an appointment?

Call us at 419-291-6767. Counseling can also be done via phone or video conference.

Can nutrition counseling help a specific condition?

Yes, nutrition often plays a big role in the treatment and recovery of certain conditions, which is why we build our nutrition counseling around your specific needs.

You can also find more information about the role of nutrition as it relates to:

  • Cancer: Proper nutrition can help you manage fatigue, nausea and other challenges.
  • Diabetes: A healthy diet can help you manage your glucose levels.
  • Heart and Vascular: The right diet can help you control cholesterol and plaque buildup.
  • Wound care: Help your body heal with the right supplements and foods.
  • High Risk Pregnancy: Proper nutrition is crucial for your baby’s best health in the womb.

To Help You Get Moving Again

It’s hard to feel your best, or to live your best life, when you’re in pain. If your bones, ligaments, muscles or joints are hurting, we’re here to help.

With services across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, you can rest easier knowing there’s high-quality orthopaedic care, close to home. Our board-certified specialists will support your every step until you’re back to the life and activities you love.

Learn more about orthopaedic services.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition where one experiences unreasonable fearful thoughts and performs ritualistic activities in order to manage those thoughts.

The frequent disturbing thoughts or images are referred to as obsessions. The repetitive rituals performed to try and dispel the obsessions are called compulsions. For example: mealtimes, bath, bedtime, and exercise are all positive routine activities. However, OCD rituals are so frequent and intense that they can interfere with your daily life.

The following are examples of obsessions:

  • Aggressive impulses, thoughts and/or behaviors
  • Counting, thinking about numbers and sequences for long periods of time
  • Excessive fear of something terrible happening
  • Extreme attention to detail
  • Intense preoccupation with dirt and germs
  • Persistent thoughts of performing extremely distasteful sexual acts
  • Preoccupation with perfection, symmetry or order
  • Preoccupation with remembering trivial things
  • Repeated doubts (for example, did I lock the door?)
  • Thoughts about violence towards someone else or their self
  • Thoughts conflicting with religious beliefs

The following are examples of compulsions:

  • Asking the same question repeatedly
  • Constant checking and rechecking (for example, checking if a door is locked)
  • Excessive counting, recounting and/or grouping
  • Hoarding objects
  • Repeated obscene words or gestures
  • Repeated words, sounds, numbers, and/or music to self
  • Repeated hand-washing (often more than 100 times a day)
  • Repeated words spoken by self or others

Causes

The exact cause is unknown, but research suggests that it’s a neurological brain disorder caused by a deficiency of the chemical, serotonin, in the brain. OCD tends to run in families.

OCD in Children and Adolescents

If you believe your child has OCD, contact your pediatrician to set up an appointment for evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. OCD can be effectively treated, usually with a combination of individual therapy and medication.

content.articleContent:
About Osteoporosis and Other Bone Conditions

You know you need to take care of your bones. But your lifestyle choices, illness, and occupation can take a toll. Learn about common bone conditions.

Osteoporosis FAQ

What is osteoporosis?

Osteoporosis is the thinning of bone tissue and loss of bone density, most often experienced by women, over time. Osteoporosis affects close to 32 million American women over 50, and nearly 2 million men between 50 and 70 years old.

How does osteoporosis affect you?

As osteoporosis progresses, the bones become more and more brittle. Thinner bones lead to fractures and broken bones, and thin bones are harder to heal. In extreme cases, your bones can be so fragile that bumping into a piece of furniture can cause a fracture. Osteoporosis can also decrease your height and put stress on your back.

What causes osteoporosis?

Menopause is one of the primary causes of osteoporosis in women. The female hormone estrogen protects women’s bones. During menopause this hormone decreases sharply. Some women lose up to 20 percent of their bone mass during menopause.

But men with certain conditions are at risk too. Cystic fibrosis, asthma, low testosterone levels, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can all lead to osteoporosis in men. Alcohol abuse and tobacco usage lead to significant damage to your bones, for both men and women.

Are you at risk?

If you answer yes to any of the following questions, talk to your doctor about a bone density test.

  • Are you over the age of 65?
  • Do you have a history of bone fractures as an adult or do you have a close relative with a history of bone fractures?
  • Do you have a family history of osteoporosis?
  • Did you have an early menopause or removal of your ovaries?
  • Do you smoke?
  • Do you have a small-boned, thin body frame?
  • Are you physically inactive?
  • Are calcium-rich foods, like dairy or leafy green vegetables, limited in your diet? Have you been told you're vitamin D deficient?
  • Do you consume alcohol on a regular basis?
  • Are you on certain medicines, such as steroids or anticonvulsants?

How can you prevent osteoporosis?

Regular exercise and a diet rich in calcium and Vitamin D strengthen your bones and prevent damage from osteoporosis. If you’re over the age of 50, you should get 1,500 milligrams of calcium and 1,000 milligrams of Vitamin D daily. Foods like eggs, cheese, low-fat milk, fish, and leafy vegetables are good sources of both calcium and Vitamin D. Spending 20 to 25 minutes in the sun is also a beneficial way to get Vitamin D.

Ask your doctor about an osteoporosis bone screening to detect osteoporosis early.

The most common test is the dual X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA) test. This measures your bone density using X-ray imagery.

What are some other bone conditions?

  • Acromegaly: Excess growth hormone production causes bones in the face, hand, and feet to grow too large.
  • Cancer: Common bone cancers include leukemia, osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma, and chondrosarcoma.
  • Fibrous Dysplasia: Swelling and abnormal growth of bones of the skull, face, ribs, upper arms, pelvis, thighs, and shins.
  • Heel spurs: Calcium deposits that form on the base of the heel bone.
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta: A genetic disorder that interrupts the production of collagen, which weakens your bones.
  • Osteomalacia: Weak and abnormal bones caused by a defect in the way your body processes vitamin D.
  • Osteomyelitis: A bacterial infection of bone requiring antibiotics and sometimes surgery.
  • Paget's Disease: Thick and enlarged, but brittle, bones caused by a malfunction in the cells that repair your bones.
  • Perthes' Disease: The head of a child’s femur (thigh bone) deteriorates because of a lack of blood supply.
  • Rickets: Weak and easily fractured bones in children due to a lack of vitamin D.

Occupational Therapy at ProMedica Total Rehab

ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including Occupational Therapy. Our licensed occupational therapists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders. These disorders include musculoskeletal such as a tendon repair; neurological such as a stroke; cognitive and emotional impairments, and limitations in functional ability due to these disorders.

How can ProMedica help you with occupational therapy?

Following a physician referral to Occupational Therapy, our therapists will work closely with you and your physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve your best possible outcome in recovery. From your session, you can expect:

  • A treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.

  • Home program designed to address your individual needs.

Where and how can I receive occupational therapy?

content.articleContent:
Rehab for Osteoarthritis

Many people with osteoarthritis believe that symptoms are inevitable and cannot be managed. Let our experts at ProMedica Total Rehab help you relieve your joint pain.

  • Have you noticed mild swelling around your joints?
  • Do you feel as though your joint pain is worse after activity or towards the end of the day?
  • Have you heard a clicking or cracking sound when a joint bends?

What is osteoarthritis?

Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis. It occurs when the cartilage in a joint breaks down due to “wear and tear” over time. This can result from overuse during a job or athletic activities. When the cartilage is damaged or gone completely, moving a joint can cause pain and friction between joints.

Can osteoarthritis be treated?

If you have osteoarthritis, talk to your doctor about treatment options. With a prescription from your physician, physical and occupational therapy can be an effective method of treatment. We believe that regular weight bearing exercise, strengthening and stretching can help to reduce or alleviate pain and improve your day to day function.

How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, we are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. Most ProMedica Total Rehab locations provide osteoarthritis care.

  • Talk to your physician to determine if this treatment is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

Our Pain Management Programs

You want ease, not an easy way out. You’re ready to be active in your pain management treatment. Connect to relief by considering the many options available to you through our pain management programs.

Our individualized pain management programs help you control your pain so that you can start living your life again.

Understanding Parkinson's Disease

Parkinson's disease is a chronic and progressive disease of the central nervous system. While it traditionally was considered to affect the motor system, it is now recognized to have a range of clinical features. In addition to movement problems, there may also be neuropsychiatric and non-motor symptoms. The exact cause of Parkinson's disease is not always clear but many symptoms are thought to result from a lack of dopamine (chemical that is responsible for transmitting signals in between the nerve cells (neurons) of the brain).

The key motor features of Parkinson's disease are:

  • Tremor that typically occurs at rest and may have a "pill rolling" appearance
  • Stiffness or rigidity of the limbs and trunk
  • Generalized slowness of movement (bradykinesia)
  • Inability to keep body in stable or balance position
  • Gait difficulty

Help Your Child Regain Control

When your child has a hard time breathing, it can be hard to catch your breath, too. That’s why our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses and respiratory therapists are here to help.

Most importantly, we make sure families understand how to help their children with the right treatments and symptom management for their pulmonology conditions.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Pelvic Congestion Syndrome

Chronic pelvic pain, defined as pain lasting six months or more, affects 15% of women in America. Many issues can cause this pain. But, did you know that a vascular problem could be one of them?

Pelvic congestion syndrome (PCS) is a condition that causes chronic pelvic pain due to problems with your veins in your lower abdomen. Veins carry blood from all areas of your body back to the heart. However, in some women, the veins in the lower abdomen have weakened, making their veins inefficient at moving the blood back up to their heart. This allows blood to build up or pool, causing pressure and bulging veins resulting in varicose veins in the pelvis.

Some sub-types of pelvic congestion syndrome include ovarian vein reflux, nutcracker syndrome, and May-Thurner syndrome.

New Procedure Offers Speedier Recovery for Patients with Nutcracker Syndrome

Who is at risk for pelvic congestion syndrome?

PCS mostly effects women of childbearing age. It is also common in women who have had two or more pregnancies and those who have a family history of venous disease.

What are the symptoms of pelvic congestion syndrome?

The main symptom of pelvic congestion syndrome is pelvic pain that lasts at least six months. Often, the pain starts during or after a pregnancy. Many women describe the pain as a severe, dull ache that worsens around the time of their menstrual period. Others describe the pain as heavy or sharp.

Other symptoms include:

  • Pain before or during a heavy menstrual flow
  • Frequent urge to urinate
  • Varicose veins on the external genitals, thighs and/or hemorrhoids

Activities that can worsen the pain include:

  • Changing your posture
  • Having sexual intercourse (pain can occur both during and after)
  • Standing or sitting for long periods of time
  • Traveling on long automobile trips or flights
  • Walking

How is pelvic congestion syndrome diagnosed?

Pelvic pain is not easy to diagnose. Your primary care provider (PCP) or gynecologist will need to consider the many possible causes of pelvic pain, including problems with your reproductive, urinary or gastrointestinal systems. To diagnose, your doctor will typically obtain a complete medical history, perform an abdominal and pelvic exam, Pap smear, and order blood work.

After ruling out other pelvic problems, a vascular expert like the ones at Jobst Vascular Institute may be consulted. This specialist may recommend additional testing such as:

  • Ultrasound – A Doppler ultrasound to check the blood flow in the pelvic blood vessels.
  • Computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) – Imaging that provides more detailed pictures of your pelvic veins.

What are the next steps?

Once you have been diagnosed with PCS, know that today more treatments than ever are available. Your gynecologist may prescribe hormone medications to relieve pain. Your gynecologist may also recommend that you talk with a Jobst vascular surgeon for additional treatment options. Most of these treatments are minimally invasive and can be performed in an outpatient setting.

To learn more about treatment options, call Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care at 877-551-VEIN (419-291-2090).

Get Back to Your Life

Talking with a doctor about your pelvic floor disorder symptoms — such as painful intercourse, leakage or constipation — can feel embarrassing. We understand. But when symptoms are disrupting your life, finding compassionate health care can help ease your pain and get you back to feeling like yourself again.

When you’re ready to talk, we’re here to listen.

Whether you’re having minor incontinence or have more serious concerns, our fellowship-trained doctors, urogynecologists and pelvic floor physical therapists will help you find a solution. Together, we’ll create a treatment plan that makes you feel healthier and more confident in your daily life.

One in every five women will have a pelvic floor disorder in their lifetime.

content.articleContent:
Treating Chronic Pelvic Pain with Physical Therapy

Pelvic floor physical therapy is an evidence-based, non-surgical approach to treating chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders. Treatment starts with an assessment by a specially-trained physical therapist (PT), who has received specialized training in evaluating and treating pelvic floor disorders. The initial evaluation typically includes:

  • Checking the motor control, strength, and endurance of core support muscles
  • Assessing your pelvic floor muscle coordination for different activities and positions
  • Other testing, as needed.

Based on the findings of this exam, the physical therapist creates a unique treatment plan to help you improve your pelvic floor function. The treatment plan may include working with you on behavioral approaches such as bladder re-training techniques. Plus, an individualized physical therapy regimen to help rehab your pelvic floor muscles. The physical therapist may use a variety of techniques. Specific treatments help to improve urinary and/or fecal continence.

Pelvic floor physical therapy is NOT…

  • Just for women. Men, women and children suffer from pelvic floor disorders and could benefit from therapy.
  • Just massage and kegels. A variety of techniques are used to treat patients.
  • Evaluation or treatment involving speculums or stirrups—neither is used in pelvic floor physical therapy
  • A “one size fits all” program. Treatment is uniquely designed to your specific needs.

How can pelvic floor physical therapy help me?

The treatments used by our pelvic floor physical therapists are designed to address issues with the structures of the pelvic floor (i.e. nerves, lymphatics, muscles, connective tissue, skin, and bones). Pelvic floor physical therapy exercises and treatments aim to improve:

  • The leakage of urine or loss of bladder control
  • Painful sex and vaginal pain
  • Sexual dysfunction (male and female)
  • Pelvic pain and discomfort in the vaginal area with or without sexual interactions
  • Pelvic organ prolapse (the dropping of the bladder, rectum or uterus)
  • Constipation or incomplete bowel or bladder emptying
  • Back, hip or sacroiliac joint (SI) pain that has not improved with time or traditional treatment

Talk to a specialist; call 419-824-1968 to schedule an appointment today.

What should I expect when I visit the pelvic floor physical therapist?

Our certified and well-trained therapists welcome you in a comfortable and friendly environment. We also believe in a team approach to care so that you are in control of your treatment.

At your first visit, we’ll do an initial evaluation that lasts about 60 minutes. This evaluation typically includes:

  • A detailed discussion including an explanation of your medical history and your condition
  • Checking the motor control, strength, and endurance of core support muscles
  • Assessing your pelvic floor muscle coordination for different activities and positions
  • An external and external and internal assessment of your pelvic floor function including strength, coordination, tone, and sensation

Based on the findings of this exam, we’ll create a unique treatment plan to help you improve your pelvic floor function. The treatment plan may include working with you on behavioral approaches such as bladder re-training techniques. Plus, an individualized physical therapy regimen to help rehab your pelvic floor muscles. The physical therapist may use a variety of techniques specific to your needs.

Kegels and More for Your Pelvic Health

Pelvic floor physical therapist may utilize a number of different therapies to treat chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders, including:

  • Stretching exercises, massage and other relaxation techniques
  • Kegel exercises: Regular, daily exercise of pelvic muscles can make the pelvic floor muscles stronger and improve, and even prevent, urinary incontinence.
  • Biofeedback: Uses different types of devices to give information on how well pelvic muscles are contracting. The message or “feedback” can help improve awareness and control of pelvic floor muscles. This is often used along with Kegel exercises to help patients gain awareness and control of the pelvic muscles.
  • Vaginal weight training: Small weights are held within the vagina by tightening the vaginal muscles.
  • Pelvic floor electrical stimulation: Mild electrical pulses stimulate muscle contractions. This may be done along with Kegel exercises.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Your Pelvic Health

The pelvic region is home to quite a few muscles and organs, including your bladder, rectum and reproductive organs. When these important parts aren’t working properly, it can cause problems, including pain and incontinence.

You're not alone in this either. One in three women of child-bearing age experiences chronic pelvic pain and one in five women experiences pelvic floor disorder.

Pelvic health issues are common, but not normal. They aren’t just part of aging or having children. Unfortunately, many people put up with it or suffer in silence because they aren’t comfortable talking about it, even with their doctor. If you think you may have a pelvic health issue, we’re here to help.

One in five women experiences a pelvic floor disorder.

Is it a pelvic health issue?

Pelvic health issues can cause a variety of symptoms in women and men. Here are some of the symptoms associated with pelvic conditions:

  • Severe steady or intermittent pain in the pelvic area
  • Pain during or after intercourse
  • Pain while having a bowel movement or urinating
  • Frequent or urgent urination
  • Leakage or passage of urine or feces
  • Constipation

Learn more about the symptoms of chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders or call 567-585-0240 to schedule an appointment

How can we help?

Our professionally trained and experienced specialists provide quality care in the diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation of chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders. We offer a wide range of surgical and nonsurgical treatment options, including pelvic floor physical therapy. We believe in an individualized and team approach to best fit your needs and lifestyle.

If you’re experiencing pelvic health symptoms, even if they are mild or bearable, we encourage you to learn more and start a conversation with your healthcare provider. Your primary care physician, OB/GYN or certified nurse midwife can refer you to one of our knowledgeable pelvic health experts.

content.articleContent:
Helping You Feel Healthier, Stronger and More Resilient

Living with chronic pain isn’t easy. It can affect every part of your day and take a toll on your mental and emotional health. That’s why it’s important to find a team who can diagnose and treat your pain with care and precision.

We don’t want chronic pelvic pain to define your life. That’s why we have a large network of specialists who can work together to pinpoint the cause of your pain. Once we find the source, we’ll create a treatment plan to fit your unique needs.

Whether you’ve been in pain for months or years, we’ll work hard to help you feel more like yourself again.

Understanding Peripheral Artery Disease

Peripheral artery disease (PAD), also known as peripheral arterial disease, occurs when narrowed arteries reduce the amount of blood flow to your legs, most commonly, but sometimes to your arms. This narrowing is caused by fatty build up, called plaque, that clings to your artery walls. This lack of blood flow causes symptoms, though you may not notice symptoms in the early stages.

 
 

Learn more about PAD with our infographic.

PAD Signs and Symptoms

 

What are the symptoms of PAD?

  • Painful cramping or aching calf, hip, or thigh muscles when walking. The cramping goes away when you rest.
  • Your leg or foot may feel better when it’s dangling off the edge of or elevated in your bed, sofa, or chair.
  • Sores on your toes, ankles, or feet that don’t heal.
  • Color changes of the skin on your legs or feet.
  • Cold leg or foot, especially when compared to your other side.
  • Shiny skin or loss of hair / slow hair growth on your leg.
  • Erectile dysfunction in men.
  • Weak or no pulse in your legs or feet.

Diagnosing PAD

 

How is PAD diagnosed?

Along with a complete medical history and physician exam, other tests include:

  • Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a comparison of the blood pressure in the ankle with the blood pressure in the arm.
  • Angiogram is an X-ray of the arteries and veins to detect blockage or narrowing. Your doctor will use a thin tube and insert it into an artery in the leg and inject a contrast dye. This makes your arteries and veins visible on the X-ray.
  • Doppler ultrasound is used to create images of blood vessels. Your doctor will use the ultrasound to measure and assess the flow of blood.

Risk Factors

  • More common in men than women
  • Diabetes
  • Smoking
  • High blood pressure
  • High cholesterol
  • Family history
  • Heart disease

If you think you’re at risk for PAD,
make these healthy lifestyle changes.

  • Eat a healthier diet.
  • Increase your physical activity.
  • Maintain a healthy blood pressure by reducing stress and taking medications as prescribed.
  • Limit your alcohol.
  • Avoid tobacco smoke.
  • Maintain a healthy weight.

Discuss further diagnosis and treatment options, like surgery and medication, and healthy lifestyle changes with your doctor.

Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.

Physical Therapy by ProMedica Total Rehab

ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including physical therapy. Our licensed physical therapists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders including musculoskeletal such as total joint replacements, and neurological impairments such as stroke.

Following a physician referral to physical therapy, our therapists will work closely with you and your physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve your best possible outcome in recovery.

From your session, you can expect:

  • A treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.
  • Follow up sessions if necessary, scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
  • Written plan of care and progress reports shared with the referring physician.
  • Home program designed to address your individual needs.

Where and how can I receive physical therapy?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide physical therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.

  • Please consult with your physician to determine if physical therapy is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

content.articleContent:
About Positron Emission Tomography (PET Scan)

Your doctor has discussed the need for a PET. Understand what it is, what to expect, and how it might benefit your health.

What is a PET?

Commonly called a PET scan, PET stands for positron emission tomography. It’s commonly requested in order to provide more information about how the following organs and tissues are working:

  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Lung
  • Breast

How does a PET scan work?

During your PET, you’ll be injected with a small amount of radioactive material, called a tracer. This tracer travels throughout your body and collects in your organs and tissues, giving your radiologist a highlighted view of the area under examination.

In order for your radiologist to assess your body’s function, you’ll lie still on a table and pass through a tunnel-like machine. This machine will detect the tracer and transform the signals into the image your radiologist will assess.

Why is a PET scan important to your health?

Generally, a PET gives your doctor a much more complete picture as to the origin or causes of symptoms you might have. Clear information means concise treatment; and focused treatment gives you the best opportunity to improve your health. Also, a PET can have results that indicate that your body is functioning just as it should, therefore ruling out serious conditions.

Understanding Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a condition that occurs after one experiences an emotionally or physically frightening event. The person is so affected by the ordeal that they develop frequent memories or flashbacks of it. When exposed to situations that resemble the traumatic event, they undergo severe emotional, mental and physical distress.

PTSD symptoms can start soon following the event and improve shortly after or they may persist long-term.

Common PTSD Symptoms

Signs vary, but you may notice any, or all, of the following:

  • Avoiding certain situations or places
  • Depression
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Experiencing physical discomfort (headaches, stomachaches)
  • Fearing death at an early age
  • Having frequent flashbacks or intrusive memories
  • Irritability
  • Loss of interest in activities you used to enjoy
  • Lost touch with reality
  • Having nightmares
  • Trouble at work or in school

Events That Trigger PTSD

Specific examples of events which typically cause PTSD:

  • Abuse – physical or emotional
  • Animal bites
  • Automobile accidents
  • Experiencing a natural disaster (such as a flood or hurricane)
  • Invasive medical procedures
  • Man-made tragedies (bombings and shootings)
  • Neglect
  • Sexual assault or molestation
  • Violent attacks (mugging, torture, kidnapping, being held captive)

If you believe you may have PTSD, schedule an appointment with a provider who works in behavioral health. Counselors, therapists, psychologists, and psychiatrists are all examples of providers who may be able to help diagnose and treat your PTSD.

PTSD in Children and Adolescents

Children and adolescents can suffer from PTSD. A child with PTSD will exhibit many of the same symptoms that an adult might. In addition to the standard symptoms, children may also begin acting younger than their age (thumb-sucking, wetting the bed). Many times, PTSD started during childhood develops into a chronic disorder. However, PTSD can be treated with therapy.

Can PTSD be prevented? As a parent, you may be able to reduce the risk of traumatic experiences in your child.

Preventing PTSD in Children and Adolescents

  • Teach your child to say NO to someone who tries to touch them inappropriately or make them uncomfortable.
  • Offer support and counseling to children who have undergone a traumatic experience.
    • Support prevention programs within your community and at your child’s school.

If you suspect your child may have PTSD, contact your pediatrician for a proper evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend a comprehensive evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional.

Find an Expert Who Advocates for Your Health

When it comes to your day-to-day health, your primary care provider is your main advocate. They are the ones who help you stay on track with prevention. They are also the first you go to when you have questions or concerns about your health. They are your trusted source for medical information and advice.

Find a Provider

content.articleContent:
Understanding Pulmonary Embolism

Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a blood clot in the lungs that develops in a blood vessel, often in the leg. It then breaks off and travels to an artery in your lung, where it suddenly blocks blood flow.

Blood clots in the lungs can be life threatening. It's important to call 9-1-1 right away if you have any unusual signs or symptoms.

Frequently Asked Questions

Pulmonary embolism: what is it?

What are the symptoms of a pulmonary embolism?

If a clot breaks off from the wall of your deep vein and is released into your bloodstream, it's called an embolus. This embolus travels through your bloodstream up to an artery in your lung. There, it suddenly blocks blood flow and can be life threatening if not treated immediately.

Blood clots in the lungs can cause:

  • Chest pain anywhere under the rib cage (may worsen with deep breathing)
  • Coughing up blood
  • Fast heart rate
  • Lightheadedness or fainting
  • Low blood pressure
  • Rapid breathing
  • Unexplained and sudden shortness of breath

What are the risk factors?

Risk factors include:

  • History of a blood clots in the legs or lungs
  • Conditions that make blood more likely to clot
  • Medical conditions/treatments such as cancer that is treated with chemotherapy
  • Birth control
  • Hormone therapy
  • Pregnancy and the first six weeks after giving birth
  • Recent surgery or trauma
  • Immobility
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Long periods of travel
  • Smoking
  • Long periods of travel

About Radiology

Radiology is the medical imaging practice of taking pictures of your internal organs in order to diagnose disease or better understand a medical condition. Your doctor may order a radiology scan in order to get a better idea of what is going on inside your body.

Our Radiology Experts

Expert diagnostic imaging is performed by fellowship-trained radiologists, who coordinate with specialized technologists and nurses. Need imaging results STAT? No problem. Wherever you are, whenever you need us, your reports are available 24/7.

You know the right test might make all the difference. When you need diagnostic imaging, what means the most to you? Board-certified radiologists. State-of-the-art technology. Thirty convenient, full-service locations. (Yes, there’s one near you.)

Rehab for Stroke and Spinal Cord Injury

The EksoNR™ is available for inpatient care at ProMedica Flower Hospital and outpatient care at ProMedica Neurosciences Center.

About Robotic Exoskeleton Therapy and Rehab

For a majority of stroke and spinal cord injury patients, regaining the ability to stand and walk is a physical and emotional challenge. A new, advanced robotic technology is now available to help get patients up and walking again.

The EksoNR™ is the first ever FDA approved, wearable robotic exoskeleton for stroke and spinal cord rehabilitation. With early and repetitive use, patients are getting up sooner after their injury, beginning to take steps sooner, and initiating gate faster.

ProMedica is the first in Northern Ohio to add this advanced technology to its comprehensive rehabilitation program. It adds another tool to what therapists can use to get their patient mobilized early.

How It Works

The EksoNR™ is designed with custom software that allows clinicians to amplify a patients’ natural ability to activate muscles and produce movement. Real-time software adjustments can be made for customized patient rehabilitation sessions. Torso support with the EksoNR™ helps to correct posture and hip width can be adjusted during sessions. Ankles are supported and kept stable. Patients report feeling secure as they re-learn correct step patterns, weight shifting and work on their posture.

Learn more through our outpatient services at 877-425-5734.

What It Means to Patients

With use of the EksoNR™, patients gain not only mobility quicker, but confidence and independence as well. The device improves:  

  • Functional Balance
  • Walking Distance
  • Gait Speed

How a Patient Gets Referred

Patients referred to therapy receive a comprehensive assessment during their evaluation. The therapist will select the exoskeleton device as a treatment intervention for pre-gait and gain activities when indicated. This intervention becomes part of the patient’s treatment plan.

Call ProMedica Total Rehab at 877-425-5734 to schedule a consultation.

Imagine a Life Without Pain – Without Surgery

Nonsurgical pain relief is within your reach. ProMedica offers a range of the most innovative regenerative medicine treatments available. Our board-certified experts bring state-of-the-art care to those in and around northwest Ohio.

content.articleContent:
Using Radiation Therapy to Treat Cancer

Radiation therapy is the use of high-energy X-rays to treat cancer. These are therapeutic X-rays, which are different from diagnostic X-rays. Radiation can be an effective cancer treatment and is designed to prevent cancer cells from growing and multiplying. The goal is to slow or stop tumor growth and, in many cases, completely destroy the tumor.

Your radiation therapy treatment is administered in stages. You’re supported by experienced professionals and caregivers along the way.

What are the steps to radiation therapy treatment?

  • Your first visit. This is a consultation to discuss your cancer and treatment options with your radiation oncologist. This is a time to ask questions. If possible, bring a family member.
  • Simulation. Your radiation oncologist uses X-ray equipment called a “simulator” to aid in your treatment plan. Sometimes, a non-toxic dye is injected in order to outline certain organs. Prior to the simulation, your radiation therapist places you into a special positioning device that will hold your body still during treatment.
  • Planning marks. During your simulation, you’re given either small black permanent marks, about the size of a freckle, or similarly sized semi-permanent marks. These marks create a focal point for the radiation treatment machine so treatment can be given to precisely the same spot each time.
  • Receiving treatments. A machine called a “linear accelerator” provides your therapeutic radiation dosages. You’ll lie on a table, sometimes shielded by protective blocks, and will be raised under the linear accelerator. The treatment machine will move to a predetermined position and apply the radiation treatment. You won’t feel or see the radiation. Expect weekly assessments while you’re given treatment to see how your body responds.
  • Follow-up care. It’s extremely important to schedule regular exams after you’ve finished your radiation treatment. This may include blood work and X-rays. Continue to maintain a healthy lifestyle after your treatment is complete.

What are the side effects of radiation therapy? Side effects differ, depending on the treatment area. The most common are fatigue and skin irritation. Your doctor or nurse will discuss ways to prevent or minimize these effects with you, including nutrition for managing fatigue.

content.articleContent:
Breathe Easier with these Respiratory and Pulmonary Services

Do you tire easily? Have a hard time catching your breath? Sometimes find it hard to sleep? Breathe easier knowing expert clinicians are here to help you with any breathing or respiratory difficulties.

What is respiratory/pulmonary care?

Respiratory/pulmonary care applies the newest technology and strategies to help you breathe easier. Whether you need help for a chronic condition such as asthma, or you need emergency services to help your lungs function, you’ll receive expert care from our respiratory care practitioners.

What conditions does respiratory/pulmonary care treat?

Our doctors, nurses, and registered respiratory therapists specialize in treating a range of chronic and acute conditions, including:

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Asthma
  • Pneumonia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Sleep disorders
  • Emphysema
  • Tobacco cessation

What types of testing help with diagnosis and treatment?

  • Pulmonary function test measures how well your lungs take in and release air, as well as how they’re able to transport gases such as oxygen from the atmosphere into your circulation.
  • Electrocardiographic test checks for problems with your heart’s electrical activity. It finds the source symptoms of heart disease like chest pain and shortness of breath.
  • Arterial blood gas test measures your acidity (pH) as well as the oxygen and carbon dioxide levels in your blood. It checks how well your lung can transport oxygen into your blood and remove carbon dioxide from your blood.

Care That Gives You Peace of Mind

Along your journey to better health, surgery may become your best option for healing. But even when it’s necessary, we know the decision to have surgery can still be stressful for many reasons. That’s why our surgical team will be with you every step of the way, from ensuring that a surgical procedure is the right decision for you to supporting your recovery until you feel like yourself again.

Research and Clinical Trials

Across ProMedica, medical professionals conduct clinical trials which have the potential to give you access to innovative treatments. 

What is a clinical trial?

A clinical trial is research plan that is designed to study a drug or device in order to evaluate how effective and safe it is for people. If you participate in a clinical trial, you may receive new or developing treatments before those treatments are widely available to the public. 

Why are clinical trials important?

Clinical trials are important because they help to determine if a medical treatment even works and which treatments work better than others. Your health and safety are always a priority. Clinical trials undergo rigorous scrutiny and are monitored regularly to ensure patients are safe and protected. If you have questions about the protections in place for patients in a clinical trial, please contact the ProMedica IRB at 419-291-5362 or email phsirb@promedica.org. 

What types of trials are available at ProMedica?

  • Cardiothoracic
  • Cardiology
  • Electrophysiology
  • Gastrointestinal
  • Heart Failure
  • Stroke
  • Vascular
  • Women’s Health and OB/GYN
  • Genitourinary
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Hemophilia
  • Adult Oncology
  • Pediatric Oncology
  • Trauma
  • Orthopaedic

In addition, you can search for clinical trials available locally or nationwide by visiting www.clinicaltrials.gov. 

How can I find a clinical trial at ProMedica that is right for me?

Please contact us for information about clinical trials at ProMedica that may be a good fit for you.

At ProMedica, we know how vital it is that those with sickle cell disease have the lifelong care they need. Our comprehensive sickle cell clinics offer preventive therapy and pain management for children and adults.

Let our family take care of yours with quality care close to home.

content.articleContent:
About Skin Cancer

You want to reduce your risk for skin cancer, or maybe you need to know what to look for. Be informed. Know the signs. Understand how to prevent this disease.

What is skin cancer?

Skin cancer is a specific form of cancer that develops most often on skin exposed to the sun. The three main skin cancer types are:

  • Basal cell carcinoma. The most common cancer form. Found in the deepest part of your skin’s outermost layer.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma. Develops in the flat, outer skin cells.
  • Melanoma. A malignant tumor that forms in the melanin-forming cells. Often appears as dark brown or black “moles” on your skin.

What skin cancer signs should you look for?

It’s important to check yourself and have a dermatologist check your skin regularly. Examine not only skin that’s regularly exposed to the sun on your face, arms, lips, and scalp, but also places rarely exposed like the bottoms of your feet, stomach, and palms of your hands. Common signs for each skin cancer type vary.

  • Basal cell carcinoma often appears as:
    • A fleshy colored, flat lesion.
    • A small, white, shiny bump.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma often appears as:
    • A flat, crusty lesion.
    • A raised, hard, red bump.
  • Melanoma often appears as:
    • A mole that changes shape, color, texture, or starts to bleed.
    • A large, brownish, speckled spot.
    • A small irregular spot that appears blue, black, red, or white around the edges.
    • Dark lesions in your mouth, lining of your vagina or anus, or on the palms of your hands, bottoms of your feet, fingertips, or toes.

What can you do to prevent it?

Skin cancer prevention is within your control. Follow these simple steps to reduce your risk:

  • Wear sunscreen all year long.
  • Avoid the sun at high points of the day.
  • Don’t use tanning beds.
  • Wear protective clothing.
  • Men and women, especially over age 18, should always request a skin exam during regular health check-ups.
  • See your dermatologist regularly for thorough skins checks, early detection, and treatment.

What type of doctor treats skin cancer?

Most skin cancers can be removed in-office by your dermatologist. However, if your skin cancer is more advanced, you may require a cancer treatment team that could include surgical oncologists, medical oncologists, or radiation oncologists.

content.articleContent:
Your Sleep Problems, Decoded

You’re at your best when you’ve had a full night’s sleep. But sometimes sleeping problems keep you from getting the rest you need.

Lack of sleep is often linked to other medical problems such as:

  • Obesity
  • Heart disease
  • Diabetes
  • Headaches
  • Depression

The good news is our sleep experts can help you get the rest your body needs.

Tired of sleep problems? Take our sleep assessment.

Common Sleep Conditions

  • Sleep apnea: breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep.
  • Narcolepsy: excessive sleepiness and frequent daytime sleep attacks.
  • Hypersomnia:excessive sleepiness, when you have trouble staying awake during the day.
  • Periodic limb movement disorder: when your limbs make rhythmic movements during sleep. Usually happens in your legs, but can also happen in your arms and shoulders.
  • Insomnia:trouble falling asleep or staying asleep through the night.

Common Symptoms

  • Feeling sleepy during the day, or falling asleep at random or irregular times.
  • Taking more than 30 minutes each night to fall asleep.
  • Awakening more than a few times or for long periods of time every night.
  • Taking frequent naps.

Sleep Tests

Depending on your symptoms, your doctor may order one or more of the following tests:

  • Polysomnography: also called a “sleep study.” It records your brain waves, the oxygen level in your blood, your heart rate, your breathing effort, and leg movements during sleep. For the most accurate results these studies are typically performed in a sleep lab. 
  • CPAP/Bi-Level trials: in-lab sleep studies used to measure continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP). These use small machines that administer positive air pressure through a tube connected to a facial mask.
  • Multiple sleep latency testing: study for excessive daytime sleepiness by measuring how quickly you fall asleep in a quiet environment during the day.
  • PAP-Nap: study to help those individuals who may be reluctant to use a PAP machine; i.e.: claustrophobia, anxiety

Treatments

Depending on your test results treatment options include:

  • PAP therapy – the most effective non-invasive cure for sleep apnea
  • Over-the-counter or prescription sleep aid medications
  • Mouthpieces
  • Relaxation exercises
  • Surgery

Treatments for Children

We are able to diagnosis and treat children age two and up at many of our sleep centers. Talk to your pediatrician if your child demonstrates any of these signs:

  • Snoring
  • Difficulty falling or staying asleep
  • Breathing pauses during sleep
  • Sleepwalking or persistent nightmares
  • Changes in mood/behavior
  • Changes in school/grades

Personalized Neck and Back Care to Ease Your Pain

Everyone deals with aches and pains at times. But when chronic pain in your back or neck starts to affect the quality of your life, you want prompt relief and treatment from a team of experts you know and trust.

ProMedica Spine Care is here to help. You’ll have easy access to the spine care you need, when you need it most.

Spine pain can develop slowly over time, result from an injury or develop from an underlying health issue. No matter how your pain started, our spine care experts are here to stop it with a personalized treatment plan for your unique needs.

About Speech Therapy

ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including Speech and Language Pathology (speech therapy).

Our licensed Speech and Language Pathologists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders. These disorders include musculoskeletal such as swallowing difficulties; neurological such as a stroke; cognitive and emotional impairments, and limitations in functional ability due to these disorders.

Following a physician referral to Speech and Language Pathology, our therapist works closely with the patient and physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve the best possible outcome in recovery. From your session, you can expect:

  • Treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.
  • Follow up sessions if necessary, scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
  • Written plan of care and progress reports shared with the referring physician.
  • Home program designed to address your individual needs.

Where and how can I receive speech language pathology services?

At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide speech language pathology services in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.

  • Please consult with your physician to determine if speech language pathology is right for you.
  • A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.

Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

A Vibrant Outlook for Your Complexion

Look forward to great skin with treatments that are backed by medical expertise. Our aesthetic services can help make a healthy, clear complexion a reality. From facials to peels to injections, all of our services are performed under the supervision of board-certified plastic surgeons.
