content.articleContent:
Set Your Mind on a Healthy Heart

Whether you were born with a structural heart disease or developed a problem later in life, you can count on ProMedica’s skilled and compassionate team for the best possible care. We’ll work with you, your family and other specialists when needed, to ensure you get high quality, coordinated and personalized treatment.

Prevention and Treatment to Keep You Active and Healthy

If you or a loved one experiences a stroke, your old life feels like it’s been put on hold. The stroke experts at ProMedica are here for you with state-of-the-art stroke care to help you get back to the life you love.

From prevention to treatment, our compassionate stroke care team is available when you need us. You’ll find us at hospitals and outpatient clinics throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. Because of our commitment to exceptional outcomes, our stroke program has earned several awards from the Get With The Guidelines® stroke initiative.

80% of strokes are preventable.

Care That Gives You Peace of Mind

Along your journey to better health, surgery may become your best option for healing. But even when it’s necessary, we know the decision to have surgery can still be stressful for many reasons. That’s why our surgical team will be with you every step of the way, from ensuring that a surgical procedure is the right decision for you to supporting your recovery until you feel like yourself again.

What are seizures?

Your brain controls how your body moves by sending out small electrical signals from your nerves to your muscles. A seizure, or convulsion, is a sudden charge of electrical activity in your brain. It occurs when irregular signals from your brain change the way your body functions. Seizures are classified into epileptic, non-epileptic or provoked seizures.

Virtual Visits

ProMedica offers telehealth services, providing you more convenient ways to get the care you need. Through telemedicine visits, both new and existing patients are able to connect to providers in more than 30 specialties by Smartphone, tablet or computer.

A telemedicine visit is just like an in-person visit, but through a secure video app within MyChart. You’ll still receive the same thorough care that you would if you were at your provider’s office.

Scheduling Your Video Visit

1. Call your provider.

Call your ProMedica provider to discuss the reason for your visit. They’ll make sure that an in-person visit isn’t necessary and determine if a telephone visit or video visit is best for you.

2. Check-in for your visit online.

Log in to ProMedica MyChart up to seven days before your telephone or video visit to complete your registration. If you don’t have a MyChart account yet, your provider’s office will help you get set up.

3. Have your appointment.

For a video visit, log on at least 15 minutes before your appointment time. For a telephone visit, your provider will give you a call at the scheduled time.

Find your ProMedica provider to schedule a MyChart video visit.

Find a doctor

How to Connect for Your Video Visit

Download Instructions

Connecting to your ProMedica MyChart Video Visit is easy as 1-2-3. Download these instructions for step-by-step directions on how to download the proper software, complete your eCheck-in and registration, and connect with your provider for your scheduled call.

  • Video Visit Instructions

    English | En Español

  • Video Visit Troubleshooting

    English | En Español

Frequently Asked Questions

Which conditions can be treated through a video visit?

Many clinical concerns can be completely addressed through video visit. This may include routine and follow-up visits as well as post-operative care.

Call your ProMedica Physicians provider today to inquire if a MyChart video visit would be appropriate for your next appointment.

Does my provider offer video visits?

More than 200 ProMedica Physicians providers are currently offering video visits. This includes primary care providers as well as specialists.

Some of the specialties currently available:

  • Allergy and Immunology
  • Behavioral Health
  • Cardiology
  • Eye Care/Ophthalmology
  • Gastroenterology
  • Hematology / Oncology
  • Neurology
  • OB/Gynecology
  • Orthopaedics
  • Wound Care
  • Pediatric Specialists
  • Pain Management

Contact your ProMedica Physicians provider to ask about your telemed options for your next visit.

What is the cost of a video visit?

Video visits offer the same level of care as in-person visits and are billed as regular office visits. Contact your insurance provider if you have questions about insurance coverage and the cost of these visits.

Can I get a prescription through a video visit?

If your provider decides you need a prescription during your telephone or video visit, they can send a prescription to the pharmacy of your choice. Similar to in-person visits, the cost of these prescriptions are not covered as part of your video visit.

Do I need a ProMedica MyChart account for a video visit?

A ProMedica MyChart account is required for a video visit, but not for a telephone visit. If you do not currently have a MyChart account, but wish to sign up for one, your provider’s office can help you when you make an appointment.

We highly recommend activating your ProMedica MyChart account even if you will be having a telephone visit; that way you are already set if a future video visit is scheduled. Through your MyChart account you can view lab results, request a prescription refill and message your provider easily and securely from the website or app.

Sign up or login to ProMedica MyChart

Will my video visit be part of my medical record?

Yes, your visit will be part of your electronic health record. A summary of your visit will also be provided to you through ProMedica MyChart.

Advanced Surgery for the Organs of Your Chest

Finding out you need thoracic surgery can feel overwhelming, especially since it involves delicate organs like your lungs, chest wall, trachea and esophagus. But at ProMedica, you can have peace of mind knowing you’re in good hands. With specialized expertise, our thoracic surgeons will care for you with skill, today’s most promising treatments and compassion.

Get Ready to Quit for Good

You have so much to gain by quitting tobacco. That’s because smoking is more than just a bad habit. It’s the leading cause of preventable death in the United States.

When you’re ready to quit smoking, the first thing you need is a plan. And because there’s no one-size-fits-all approach, you’ll likely need a range of tools and programs to help you stop using tobacco products.

At ProMedica, our highly skilled and experienced staff of respiratory therapists and registered nurses will tailor your plan for quitting. It will address your dependence on nicotine and build habits and behaviors to help you stay tobacco free.

Understanding Ultrasound

Ultrasound is a technique that uses sound waves and a computer to create pictures of the inside of your body. Ultrasound gives your doctor a clearer picture of your tissue and organs so you get a concise diagnosis and the most effective treatment. Your doctor may order an ultrasound for your:

  • Heart
  • Kidneys
  • Liver
  • Blood Vessels
  • Fetus if you’re pregnant
  • Other organs or body parts

What can you expect from your ultrasound?

It’s a simple and painless procedure that can be done right in your doctor’s office or at one of our radiology centers.

You’ll lie on a table while your doctor or ultrasound technician guides a smooth instrument over your skin in the targeted area. Though you won’t hear them, sound waves are sent through your body where they’ll bounce off your body’s tissues. The instrument also receives the sound waves that bounce back. The ultrasound machine will interpret these into a picture that your doctor can review and then make an assessment.

Immediate Care When You Need It Most

When the unexpected happens, you need care that’s convenient and fast. ProMedica Urgent Care is here to treat injuries and illnesses that don’t require a trip to the emergency room. Walk-ins are welcome. No appointment is necessary.

We treat children of all ages at ALL of our ProMedica Urgent Care locations; however, ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids in Perrysburg is only for kids under the age of 18.

If you or a loved one have a life-threatening health emergency like a heart attack, stroke, limb-threatening injuries, unconsciousness or a severe allergic reaction, please call 911 right away.

We’re open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., 365 days a year. You don’t need to make an appointment.

Expert, Compassionate Care for Lasting Relief

When losing control of your bladder disrupts your life, it’s important to get treatment. The urinary specialists at ProMedica are here to help diagnose and treat a wide range of bladder-related issues. From occasional incontinence to a urinary tract infection, we can help you heal and get back to the life you love.

You aren’t alone. Over 26 million people in the United States have urinary issues.

Understanding UTIs

Urinary tract infections or UTIs are infections in any part of the urinary tract. They are a common health problem that affects millions of people each year. Women are especially prone to UTIs.

Treating Urinary Tract Infections

Our providers will figure out the best treatment for your UTI based on:

  • How old you are
  • Your overall health and past health
  • How sick you are
  • How well you can handle specific medicines, procedures, or therapies
  • How long the condition is expected to last
  • Your opinion or preference

Treatment for UTIs may include:

  • Antibiotics
  • Other medicines to ease pain
  • Heat (such as heating pad) to ease pain

Our providers provide safe, effective UTI treatment to thousands of patients each year.

content.articleContent:
Advanced Valve Surgery Techniques to Restore Your Heart Health

Valve surgery is one of the most common treatments for valve disease. But when you’re faced with having a valve replaced or repaired it can feel far from ordinary. At ProMedica, we apply our research-driven approach to advanced heart surgery methods. These include traditional open-heart surgery and minimally invasive procedures to help restore your heart health.

Give Your Body the Blood Flow It Needs

Vascular disease prevents your body from getting the blood flow it needs to work properly. With symptoms that can be hard to recognize, it’s important to know your risks and get a screening for vascular disease if needed. Early and effective treatment is the best way to lower your chance of serious complications.

About the Vascular Lab

After a provider takes a detailed medical history and completes a physical exam, testing in a vascular laboratory is often the next step in diagnosing your vascular disease. Jobst Vascular Institute’s accredited vascular laboratory performs more than 30,000 studies each year, including many vascular ultrasounds.

These studies help your doctor understand what’s going on with your circulatory system. That body system includes the blood vessels outside of your heart, which carry blood to parts of your body like your brain, abdomen and extremities.

Who performs vascular lab tests?

Our highly dedicated, well-trained and credentialed vascular technologists will do all that they can to make you feel comfortable during your visit to our vascular lab. We are very proud of our vascular testing accreditation through the Intersocietal Accreditation Commission. It’s one more way to show you how we ensure excellent, quality testing for you.

Also good to know: The tests, including vascular ultrasounds, in our labs are non-invasive. That means there’s no need to insert an instrument or device through your skin or into your body. There is also no exposure to radiation because we use sound waves. 

Once completed, all of our studies are reviewed by one of our board-certified vascular physicians.

Jobst Vascular Laboratory is also an education site for local vascular ultrasound training programs including: Owens Community College and Jackson College.

Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.

What kinds of vascular studies are offered?

Jobst Vascular Laboratory is a full-service laboratory that provides many different types of state-of-the-art diagnostic tests. But vascular ultrasound is the most important tool in our lab and the one we use the most.

A duplex vascular ultrasound uses sound waves to take pictures of your vessels and a Doppler to listen to blood flow through your arteries and veins. The exam is painless and easy for you. But it provides invaluable information for your physician.

Studies performed in our vascular lab include:

  • Cerebrovascular studies of the blood flow to the brain: Carotid artery duplex, transcranial artery Doppler (TCD)
  • Venous: DVT (deep venous thrombosis), CVI (chronic venous insufficiency)
  • Arterial studies to determine the amount of blood flow in your arms and legs: ankle-brachial Index (ABI), pulse volume recording (PVR), segmental pressures, duplex scan graft surveillance
  • Abdominal studies to check the blood flow in the arteries and veins in the abdominal cavity: ultrasound of the inferior vena cava, aorta, kidney and visceral arteries

Where are your labs located?

We have several vascular labs in convenient ProMedica locations across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.Each of these locations provides vascular ultraound services.

title: Varicose Veins and Spider Veins | ProMedica

content.articleContent:
Say Hello to Healthy Legs

Uncomfortable and sometimes unsightly, varicose and spider veins can make you feel like you need to hide your legs. But the good news is that both are treatable. The first step is knowing how to tell the difference between these common, but often confused, conditions.

ProMedica Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care brings together an experienced and specialized team. These providers diagnose and treat varicose veins and spider veins, as well as vascular birthmarks.

As Northwest Ohio's largest group of board-certified vascular surgeons, vascular medicine specialists and advanced practice providers, we’re trained in all aspects of vascular disease. In our vein clinic, we use the latest technologies so we can identify not only the surface problem, but its underlying causes.

Schedule a free screening with one of our vein specialists.

Contact Us

Your vascular team offers expert care that’s close to home.

When you or a loved one needs treatment for a vascular problem, you want to spend your time getting healthy. You don’t want to travel here and there visiting specialists. With Jobst Vascular Institute, you’ll have expert care right where you live.

Jobst Vascular Institute offers you access to world-class vascular care that’s close to home. You may live in northwest Ohio or southeast Michigan — no matter which region it is, your skilled specialists will be by your side.

Rest easy when you visit a ProMedica specialist. Our network will help coordinate every part of your treatment. Whether you need testing, medical treatment or surgery, you can expect well-connected care.

Learn more about our vascular services.

View our 2021 annual report

About Vascular Surgery

With the largest group of board-certified and fellowship-trained vascular surgeons in the area, the team at Jobst Vascular Institute stands ready to provide the high quality vascular surgery care at ProMedica Toledo Hospital and other ProMedica locations.

What is vascular surgery?

Vascular surgery focuses on the surgical treatment of disease in your circulatory system outside of your heart and brain. This includes your arteries, veins and lymphatic system:

  • Arteries: Blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body.
  • Veins: Blood vessels that carry blood from the body back into the heart.
  • Lymphatic system: A network of vessels throughout the body that drains lymph fluid from tissues to maintain fluid balance and to clear byproducts of inflammation.

What vascular diseases do you treat?

Our vascular surgeons treat and manage acute and chronic vascular diseases including:

  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Blood clotting disorders
  • Carotid artery stenosis
  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism
  • Dialysis access for patients with kidney disease
  • Lymphedema
  • Peripheral artery disease (PAD)
  • Spider and varicose veins
  • Swollen legs
  • Venous and lymphatic diseases
  • Venous ulcers
  • Wound care

Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.

What vascular surgery services are available?

Vascular surgery for vascular disease may be required and includes both open and endovascular repair:

  • Angioplasty and stenting for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
  • Arteriovenous Fistula formation
  • Atherectomy for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
  • Carotid angioplasty and stenting
  • Carotid endarterectomy
  • Dialysis access
  • Endovascular repair of aortic aneurysm
  • Endovenectomy
  • Open bypass for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
  • Open repair of aortic aneurysm
  • Thrombolysis for extensive deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
  • Wound debridement

When is vascular surgery recommended?

If the doctor suspects that a person may have decreased blood flow somewhere in the peripheral (arms, legs, and/or neck) circulation, vascular studies may be performed. Using these studies and other information, the surgeon will decide on the best course of treatment for the patient.

Vascular Neurology at ProMedica Toledo Hospital

At ProMedica Toledo Hospital, expect only the best in vascular neurological services. Our highly-trained, specialized physicians provide care in a state-of-the-art, 20-bed stroke unit with a neuro-interventional lab. The facility features private rooms, a portable CT scanner, 24-hour MRI service, and nursing staff specifically trained in caring for people with complex neurological conditions.

Our vascular neurological services are offered throughout Toledo Hospital and coordinated by your physician specialist.

Conditions and diseases treated:

  • Aneurysms
  • Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs): including spinal AVMs
  • Dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVF)
  • Hemorrhagic strokes: including subarachnoid hemorrhages and intracerebral hemorrhages
  • Ischemic strokes: including thrombotic strokes, embolic strokes
  • Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)

Procedures and treatments performed:

  • Aneurysm treatment: coil embolization, pipeline flow diversion device, surgical clipping
  • Angioplasty
  • Carotid artery stenting
  • Carotid endarterectomy
  • Clot busters: tPA; including intra-arterial tPA
  • Clot Evacuation
  • Hemicraniectomy
  • Mechanical thrombectomy
  • Nasal embolization
  • Tumor embolization
  • Ventriculostomy or External Ventricular Drain (EVD)

Testing available:

  • Carotid ultrasound
  • Cerebral angiography
  • CT
  • CTA
  • CT Perfusion
  • Echocardiogram: transthoracic, transesophageal
  • MRI
  • MRA
  • MRV
  • Transcranial doppler
  • WADA testing

What Is a Vasectomy?

A vasectomy is a permanent and effective form of birth control for men. During the procedure, your vas deferens, the tube that carries sperm from your testes, is cut and sealed. This blocks sperm from reaching semen so that, when ejaculated, it cannot get a woman pregnant.

The procedure typically takes 20-30 minutes and is safe with few side effects. Usually within a couple of days, you’re feeling better and back to your normal routine.

Call 1-844-855-TEAM for a consultation.

Types of Vasectomies

Two most common types include:

  • Conventional vasectomy. During this more traditional method, small cuts are made on each side of the scrotum to reach the vas deferens, which are cut, tied or fastened with a metal clip.
  • No scalpel vasectomy. This newer, more modern method is done through one tiny hole in the skin. A tool is used to gently stretch the skin opening so that the vas deferens can be reached. Because no cuts are made, there is little bleeding. It heals quickly with little or no scarring.

Debunking the Myths about Vasectomy

It’s normal to have questions and concerns about a vasectomy, but sometimes myths about the procedure can lead to unfounded concerns. Here’s the truth about vasectomies. A vasectomy:

  • Won’t affect your sexual performance. A vasectomy won’t affect your sex drive or your masculinity in any way other than preventing you from fathering a child. Men have even reported higher sexual satisfaction after a vasectomy.
  • Is safe for your sexual organs. There's very little risk that your testicles, penis or other parts of your reproductive system will be injured during surgery.
  • Doesn't increase your risk of certain cancersAlthough there have been some concerns about a possible link between having a vasectomy and getting testicular or prostate cancer in the past, there's no proven link.
  • Doesn’t increase your risk of heart disease. As with cancer fears, there doesn't appear to be any link between vasectomy and heart problems.
  • Causes minor, not severe, pain. You might feel minor pain and pulling or tugging during surgery, but severe pain is rare. Likewise, after surgery you might have some pain, but for most men the pain is minor and goes away after a few days.

ProMedica Vasectomy FAQs

Is a vasectomy right for me?

Choosing a vasectomy as a form of birth control is a major decision. You should be 100% sure that it is the right decision for you before undergoing this procedure. You and your partner should talk about the decision to not have any more children. Having a vasectomy may be a good choice if:

  • You are an adult male and you are either done having children or don’t want to have children.
  • You are in a stable relationship and both partners agree to permanent birth control.
  • Pregnancy would be a health risk for your partner.
  • You or your partner has a genetic disorder that you don’t want to pass on to a child.

To learn more about a vasectomy and ask questions to determine if it is right for you, schedule a consultation with one of our board-certified urologists.

How do I prepare for a vasectomy?

It is important that you share your medical history with the doctor; include information about drugs (both prescription and over-the-counter), as well as supplements, you are taking. Be sure to tell your doctor about any drug allergies or bleeding conditions you have.

Your physician will tell you about any specific things you need to do (and know) to get ready for your procedure. Follow directions and recommendations as explained during the consultation. Wear comfortable, close-fitting underwear. It is recommended that you bring someone to drive you home after the procedure.

What happens during a vasectomy?

This procedure is most often done in our outpatient surgery center. Your vasectomy will most often be done under local anesthesia, but sedation is available for those who need it. The area will be numbed, but typically you will be awake. It takes about 20 - 30 minutes to complete the procedure.

Generally, here’s what happens during a vasectomy:

  • You will be asked to remove any jewelry or other objects that might get in the way during the procedure.
  • You will remove your clothing and put on a hospital gown.
  • You will be asked to empty your bladder.
  • You will lie on your back on an exam table.
  • Your scrotum may be shaved and cleaned with an antiseptic solution or special soap.
  • The surgeon will inject a numbing medicine into your scrotum.
  • The doctor will make either a small cut or opening on one side of your scrotum to find the vas deferens, which will be cut, tied or fastened with a metal clip. The site is closed and a bandage applied. The procedure is repeated on the other side of the scrotum to block the second vas deferens.
  • In many cases, both vas deferens can be reached through the same hole.
  • In some cases, small stitches or skin glue may be used to close the cuts.

What happens after a vasectomy?

You will likely be able to go home soon after surgery. The staff will watch you closely and the doctor may give you pain medication. You may be told to use an ice pack for the first day to reduce pain and swelling. Here is what you may expect during recovery:

  • Rest at home the day after surgery. Don't do any strenuous activity. Avoid standing or walking too long.
  • Depending on the type of work you do, you may be able to go back in 1 to 3 days.
  • You should be able to return to most activities in a week, but avoid heavy lifting and hard exercise for up to 1 to 3 weeks.
  • You may need to wear a jock strap for a few days.
  • You should not bathe or swim until 1 to 2 days after your vasectomy.
  • You may be able to return to sexual activity in about a week, but you should continue to use another form of birth control until the doctor tests the semen to be sure there are no sperm left. This test is often performed about two months after surgery. It is important to know that vasectomies will occasionally fail and checking semen samples afterwards to confirm sterility is strongly recommended.

Vasectomy is very safe, but all surgeries carry some risks. Tell your doctor if you have any of the following:

  • A lump in your scrotum
  • Any drainage, bleeding, redness, or swelling
  • Fever
  • Chills
  • Increasing pain or pain that is not eased by medicine
  • Trouble passing urine
  • Bleeding disorders

Can I have my vasectomy reversed?

Possibly. Some vasectomies may be reversed, but the process can be more difficult than the actual vasectomy, isn’t always successful and can be expensive. Many insurance providers do not cover reversals.

title: Varicose Veins and Spider Veins | ProMedica

Say Hello to Healthy Legs

Uncomfortable and sometimes unsightly, varicose and spider veins can make you feel like you need to hide your legs. But the good news is that both are treatable. The first step is knowing how to tell the difference between these common, but often confused, conditions.

ProMedica Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care brings together an experienced and specialized team. These providers diagnose and treat varicose veins and spider veins, as well as vascular birthmarks.

As Northwest Ohio's largest group of board-certified vascular surgeons, vascular medicine specialists and advanced practice providers, we’re trained in all aspects of vascular disease. In our vein clinic, we use the latest technologies so we can identify not only the surface problem, but its underlying causes.

Schedule a free screening with one of our vein specialists.

Contact Us

Ready to lose weight? We’ll take the journey with you.

Losing weight can seem like an uphill climb, especially if you’ve been on that hill before. At ProMedica, we can give you the structure and support you need to reach your goal. Learn more about our options and find the right fit for you.

content.articleContent:
Helping You Heal When You’re Hurting

Cuts and scrapes are part of our daily life. When a band-aid or over-the-counter cream won’t do the trick, you may have something more serious.

If you have a wound, you need to know how to take care of it. That’s why the expert team at ProMedica Wound Care is here for you with education and treatment to help you heal.

You’re an important part of your wound healing process.

Understanding X-ray

General radiology most often refers to diagnostic x-rays used to help identify disease or injury inside the body. X-ray— using radiation passing through the body to produce an image on a special film —was discovered in 1885, and is considered a milestone in the development of modern medicine. For the first time, physicians were able to see inside the body to detect injury and disease, often in its early stages when the illness or injury is most treatable.

What to Expect During an X-ray

During an x-ray, a machine is used to send x-rays through your body. Radiation is absorbed by the more dense parts of your body, which produces a lighter image on the x-ray picture called a radiograph. The less dense areas of the body (soft tissue) absorb less radiation and appear darker on the x-ray.

Common x-ray studies used to detect disease and injury include:

  • Chest Exam - used to diagnose diseases of the heart and lungs
  • Bone Studies - used to determine the relationship between bones and visualize fractures
  • Digestive System Studies - used to detect diseases such as ulcers and tumors.
  • Searching for Foreign Bodies - used to locate objects in the body that should not be there
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - Used to study the kidneys and ureters to the bladder.
